Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, we rely on and refer to information regarding our business and the markets in which we operate and compete. Certain economic and industry data, market data and market forecasts set forth in this Offering Memorandum were extracted from market research, governmental and other publicly available information, independent industry publications and reports prepared by industry consultants. These external sources include Roland Berger and AgbioInvestor, among others. We cannot assure you that any of the assumptions that the providers of the data reports have made in compiling this data are accurate or correctly reflect our position in the relevant markets. In addition, the markets in which we operate and compete may have shifted or changed since the date that each data report was prepared. Therefore, the data reports may not accurately reflect certain aspects of the current market and industry. Further, the providers of the data reports do not warrant, represent or guarantee the accuracy and completeness of any information in this Offering Memorandum, and neither do the providers of the data reports accept any responsibility or liability to any party who relies on any information contained in this Offering Memorandum. Further, certain of the information contained in this Offering Memorandum is based on reports prepared for us by Roland Berger, AgbioInvestor and other third-party sources. Accordingly, such information may be less objective or reliable than information prepared by an independent third party. As we do not have access to the facts and assumptions underlying the market data, statistical information and economic indicators contained in third-party sources, we are unable to verify such information and cannot guarantee its accuracy or completeness. We also do not have access to the facts and assumptions underlying the projections made in the market data obtained from the data reports, or the other third-party reports that contributed to any of the data reports. Various economic and other factors may cause actual results to differ from these projections. Certain data and information referenced herein is derived from reports by market research firms, including the Roland Berger Report. Data and information from the Roland Berger Report referenced herein are the copyrighted property of Roland Berger. The Roland Berger Report has been prepared based on sources considered reliable; however, the accuracy and completeness of such sources and the information included in the report are not warranted, nor are the opinions and analyses provided by Roland Berger representations of fact. The Roland Berger Report speaks as of the original publication date thereof and is subject to change without notice. Roland Berger and other trademarks appearing in the Roland Berger Report are the property of Roland Berger or their respective owners. To the extent permitted by law, Roland Berger shall not be liable for any errors or omissions or any loss, damage or expense incurred by reliance on the Roland Berger Report or any statement contained herein, or resulting from any omission. No portion of the Roland Berger Report may be reproduced, reused, or otherwise distributed in any form without the prior written consent of Roland Berger. Content reproduced or redistributed with Roland Berger’s permission must display Roland Berger legal notices and attributions of authorship. While we accept responsibility for accurately summarizing the information from these external sources, and as far as we are aware and able to ascertain no facts have been omitted which would render this information inaccurate or misleading, we accept no further responsibility in respect of such information. Certain information in this Offering Memorandum, including without limitation, statements regarding the industry in which we operate, our position in the industry, our market share and the market shares of various industry participants are based in part on our internal estimates and analyses and based in part on third-party sources. We cannot assure you that our estimates or any of the assumptions underlying our estimates are accurate or correctly reflect our position in the industry. None of our internal surveys or information has been verified by any independent sources. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers make any representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of this information. All of the information set forth in this Offering Memorandum relating to the operations, financial results or market share of our competitors has been obtained from publicly available information or independent research. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers have independently verified this information and cannot guarantee its accuracy. Certain market share information and other statements presented herein regarding our position relative to our competitors with respect to the manufacture or distribution of particular products are not based on published statistical data or information obtained from independent third parties, but reflects our best estimates. We have based these estimates upon information obtained from our customers, trade and business organizations and associations and other contacts in our industry as well as the Roland Berger Report. These estimates have been derived from management’s knowledge and experience in the markets in which we operate, as well as information obtained from public third-party industry reports and from our customers, distributors, suppliers, trade and ii ----- business organizations and other contacts in the markets in which we operate. We also provide certain estimates of the growth of markets and certain other projections related to our industry. This information is inherently speculative and subject to risk. Because such data is often incomplete, multiple sources are typically triangulated to develop consensus estimates. Market data and statistics, including information regarding penetration rates and growth, volume and growth and other information about particular regions or markets, are inherently predictive and speculative and are not necessarily reflective of actual market conditions. Such statistics are generally based on market research, which itself is based on sampling and subjective judgments by both the researchers and the respondents. In addition, the value of comparisons of statistics of different markets is typically limited by many factors, including that (i) the underlying information was gathered by different methods with varying levels of access and information available in different markets and (ii) different assumptions were applied in compiling the data. Market studies are frequently based on information and assumptions that may not be exact and their methodology is by their nature forward-looking and speculative. Furthermore, certain forward-looking statements contained in such industry and certain market data may not fully include the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, geopolitical tensions relating to the Russia-Ukraine conflict, or other related developments, including the impacts of future national or local lockdowns or other measures implemented by national and/or local authorities. There can be no assurance that such forward-looking statements would not have been materially different if such developments related to the COVID-19 pandemic or the impact resulting from the conflict in Ukraine had been taken into account. See “Forward-looking Statements.” Further, please be aware that data and statistical information in this Offering Memorandum may differ from estimates made by our competitors or from information found in current or future studies conducted by market research institutes, consultancy firms or independent sources. While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding the industry or similar data presented herein, such data involves risks, assumptions and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed under the heading “Risk Factors.” iii -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading CDMO (contract development and manufacturing organization) and fine chemistry manufacturer with global operations, supplying customized ingredients to major players in the Western Crop Science market, as well as high purity and high-complexity chemical ingredients to customers in the Life Science and Performance Material markets. Our strong technology portfolio, technical know-how and execution capabilities allow us to cover a wide spectrum of highly specialized customer needs, specifications and complexity profiles. Headquartered in Germany, we operate a global network with six production facilities located in Pratteln (Switzerland), Kokkola (Finland), Galena (Kansas, United States), Gersthofen (Germany), Knapsack (Germany) and Jining, Shandong Province (China). Our varied product portfolio is organized across two product groups: (i) Exclusives (tailor-made active ingredients and precursors developed for individual customers on an exclusive basis (our CDMO offering)) and Specialties (highly specialized ingredients with applications in high-margin end-markets) products and (ii) Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals products (intermediate and base chemical products such as high purity monochloroacetic acid (“MCA”), chloroacetyl chloride (“CAC1”) and caustic soda across a large purity spectrum with multiple end-use applications). Our products are deeply embedded into our customers’ value chains, often on a near-exclusive basis, allowing us to be aligned in demand planning and supply chain coordination and to set up scalable manufacturing facilities and efficient commercial production processes. The combination of our production know-how, lengthy product development processes and contractually agreed capital expenditure contributions for some of our products typically result in high contract renewal rates and low customer churn. For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, we generated revenue of €755.5 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of €162.6 million (21.5% Adjusted EBITDA margin). Between 2020 and 2022, our revenue grew at 23.9% CAGR, whereas our Adjusted EBITDA grew at 20.0% CAGR. Exclusives and Specialties contributed to 56.8% of our revenue for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 whereas Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals accounted for 43.2% of our revenue for the same period. Our products are used for end-market applications mainly in: (i) Crop Science (e.g., herbicides, fungicides, insecticides and other livestock and crop protection products), (ii) Life Science (e.g., pharma, personal care, nutrition, fragrances and flavor applications) and (iii) Performance Materials (e.g., curatives in epoxies, polyimides, polyesters and other resin systems used for electronic components, semiconductors and for composites, fibers, films, and foams that provide heat and electrical resistance). These end-markets, in particular Crop Science, have shown resilient historical growth rates and benefit from structural mega-trends that are expected to drive further resilient growth in the near- to mid-term, such as increasing demand for food and need for increased farming yields on the one hand, and an aging population and improving living standards on the other. In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of our products were used in the Crop Science market, approximately 20% in the Life Science market, approximately 15% in the Performance Materials market and approximately 15% relate to others (e.g., base chemicals and industrial MCA) (measured as a percentage of revenues). Exclusives, our CDMO offering, provides tailor-made active ingredients and precursors tailored to individual customer specifications in Crop Science and are a primary contributor to our overall profitability. Based on customer-developed IP, these products require customized production lines, expansive know-how and close cooperation with our customers. We offer development and manufacturing services for proprietary products on an exclusive and confidential basis to leading players in the Crop Science market such as: BASF, Bayer, Corteva and Syngenta, and we have relationships with nearly all major players in the Western Crop Science market. 1 ----- Our Specialties offering consists of specialty ingredients that leverage our considerable manufacturing expertise to create complex chemical products that serve specific customer needs across a variety of applications in the Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials industries. Unlike Exclusives, these products can be offered to multiple customers at a time. Our offering highlights our excellent production capabilities and knowhow along with our ability to offer specialized technology process and development services which allows us to continuously provide high-quality and purity products to our customers and which we believe is a key differentiator in this field. Our Specialties products are also a strong contributor to profitability, leveraging our close client relationship and high customer “stickiness”. In particular, we offer high value-add products for fastgrowing applications in Life Science (pharma and personal care as well as nutrition) and Performance Materials markets (coatings, e.g., in electronics or other industrial applications), backed by several attractive long-term customer contracts, which offer high visibility on the lifecycle and returns on our products. Customers for our Specialties products include players such as Agilent Technologies, Bayer, Corteva, Deciem/Estee Lauder, DSM, Evonik, Merck, Novartis and Syngenta. In our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals product group, we offer intermediate and base chemical products, such as MCA, CAC1 and caustic soda, that serve as chemical building blocks for other secondary chemical processes with a variety of applications across a large number of industries and markets. We believe we are one of the leading suppliers of MCA to Western Europe and the Americas and we operate state-of-the-art sites, allowing us to provide a full range of purity and quality for our customers. Large parts of our Advanced Intermediates supply agreements feature price formulas that allow us to partially pass on price increases in costs of certain raw materials. Furthermore, we also generate a portion of our revenue from Base Chemicals and other products such as caustic soda, that are generated as by-products from our Exclusives and Advanced Intermediates production lines.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Structurally growing end-markets and increasing outsourcing trends
Subsubsection Text: Our underlying key end-markets (Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials) are enjoying strong and resilient underlying growth, further supported by increasing outsourcing trends that are reinforcing demand for our Crop Science CDMO offering. In the financial year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 70% of our revenue was generated in the Crop Science and Life Science markets (estimate based on internal company assessments), the majority of which consists of our CDMO offering through our Exclusives products and to a smaller degree of contributions from our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals products. As a result, growth in the underlying Crop Science and Life Science markets, specifically within CDMO products and novel advanced intermediates, represent key growth levers for our business. _Crop Science_ Our addressable CDMO Crop Science market grew by 9% to 10% CAGR between 2019 and 2022, outperforming the underlying global market for Crop Science products which grew by approximately 8% CAGR during the same period (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor). Market research indicates continued growth until 2027 with respect to both our addressable CDMO Crop Science market (4% to 5% CAGR from 2022 to 2027) and the underlying global market for Crop Science products (2% CAGR) (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor). For more information on the specific historical and projected growth of the addressable CDMO Crop Science and underlying global Crop Science markets, see “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺General.” The growth in the underlying global Crop Science market in particular is underpinned by the following megatrends (see “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺Key Drivers” for a more detailed overview) (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor): - Growing population: global population growth drives demand for food and crops; and - Decreasing arable land: arable land per capita is decreasing, requiring efficient crop protection products to increase farming yields. These market dynamics are further supported by several specific trends in the addressable CDMO Crop Science market, including (see “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺Key Drivers” for a more detailed overview) (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor, Company Information): 2 ----- - Growth in CDMO outsourcing: customers prioritizing research and development, sales and marketing and digitalization activities and striving to reduce their capital intensity and costs (in 2022, approximately 40% to 50% of active ingredient production by Crop Science Players was outsourced to CDMOs); - Increasing complexity of active ingredient molecules: requires specialist CDMO partners with strong technical expertise and assets fitting into global supply chains of Crop Science players; and - Increasingly stringent regulatory requirements: lead to higher demand for novel active ingredients, often outsourced to CDMOs with highly efficient multi-purpose facilities. Furthermore, historical demand for crop protection products has proven to be resilient to adverse events maintaining a growth trend in spite of temporary downturns. For example, declines in average crop commodity prices (e.g., corn, wheat, soybean) caused by events such as lower pest pressure and economic recessions in production markets such as in Brazil, and North American weather conditions in 2019 led to a temporary downturn in the crop protection market but were followed by year-on-year increases. Furthermore, while agrochemical production was impacted by coronavirus-related restrictions in the first quarter of 2020, it swiftly normalized following an easing of lockdown restrictions. While the coronavirus restrictions did impact labor availability both in terms of production and field work, many countries deemed the agricultural sector to be of considerable importance in maintaining food security, so restrictions on movement were less severe than in most industries (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). The addressable market for novel active ingredients (active ingredients introduced after 2010), a subset of the CDMO Crop Science market, is anticipating significantly higher growth rates at a CAGR of approximately 13.7% from 2021 to 2027, owing to, among other factors, a higher outsourcing rate due to production complexity (Roland Berger Report). Against this background, we act as a key partner for our clients in this area, supporting innovators with our technical expertise and state-of-the-art production facilities. Our Crop Science product portfolio benefits from a modern set of active ingredients. We are not materially involved in the production of raw materials or finished product for glyphosate or neonicotinoids. _Life Science_ Our Specialty products benefit from the strong underlying growth rates in a number of attractive niche markets for specialized Life Science applications. In 2022, the addressable Life Science market accounted for the second largest portion of our revenue after the Crop Science market. Our products in this area consist primarily of Advanced Intermediates products as well as Specialties products. Our addressable Life Science markets grew between 2019 and 2022 and are expected to grow further, driven by structural mega-trends including a global aging population and an increasing disposable income spent on personal care, showing the strength of this segment for our future growth potential (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). For more information on trends driving Life Sciences growth (including niche markets), see “Industry and Market Data⸺Life Science⸺Key Drivers.” Individual addressable high growth sub-markets such as the oligonucleotide synthesis market (used for the production of synthetic RNA and DNA templates) increased significantly in 2021 and 2022, and forecasts are estimating future significant growth. See also “Industry and Market Data⸺Life Science⸺General⸺DCA.” While this is in part due to the market’s limited current size, it also highlights how we may be able to leverage our technical excellence to capitalize on developing demand for high-purity ingredients. For example, we are the global market leader and only large-scale Western supplier of high purity grade DCA (a key ingredient for RNAbased medication) in Life Science for pharmaceutical applications (by high purity DCA revenue as of 2022). Furthermore, DCA applications in the production of synthetic RNA and DNA templates have wider uses in the Life Sciences industry than COVID-19 applications (where mostly enzymatic synthesis is employed), so our product has only some commercial exposure to the trends driving COVID-19 vaccines and will benefit from growing end markets due to both increased investments into research and development (e.g. improvement of genomic technologies) as well as broader commercial use (e.g. “oligonucleotide therapeutics”), see “Industry and _Market Data⸺Life Science⸺DCA⸺Key Drivers” (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). Performance Materials_ Our Specialties products with niche applications benefit from attractive market dynamics in addressable endmarkets in the Performance Materials segment, BTDA, 6FDA and other markets, which are expected to grow 3 ----- until 2027 (Roland Berger Report). For more information on projected growth rates, see “Industry and Market _Data⸺Performance Materials⸺Specialty Anhydrides⸺General and “Industry and Market Data⸺Performance Materials⸺Electronic Performance Materials Product⸺General.”_ Our BTDA and 6FDA products are used for numerous applications in electronics, infrastructure and transportation and benefit from favorable macro trends in these sectors, such as growth in smart devices, the switch to 5G infrastructure and higher government and industry spending on infrastructure. Our electronic performance materials product is primarily used in the semiconductor industry, which fundamentally benefits from (i) the introduction of new generation semiconductors, (ii) increasing electrification (e.g., autonomous driving and digital connectivity) and (iii) the rise of artificial intelligence enabled by semiconductors (Roland Berger Report).

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Leading Crop Science CDMO and Differentiated Life Science Ingredients Player with Global Presence
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading player in the Western Crop Science CDMO market, serving major global agrochemicals companies and holding strategic supplier status with some of the largest European-based Crop Science companies for their agrochemicals business. We are among the top two Western CDMO players in the Crop Science market (by Crop Science CDMO revenue as of 2021). We have a strong focus on novel active ingredients, directly competing with only a select number of other Tier 1 players that are able to serve this segment. We are wellpositioned within the top five players globally in the Crop Science market (measured by Crop Science CDMO revenue as of 2021) due to strong customer relationships, diverse and unique asset footprint and technical knowhow (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). We also have a significant presence in the Life Science market, providing customized products in segments such as novel RNA therapeutics, vitamins and supplements, and anti-aging and personal care and hold leading positions in the markets for European MCA supply, high purity DCA, as well as CAE manufacturing and cosmetic grade GA in Life Science: We are one of the largest European Life Science MCA suppliers (by production volume in Europe as of 2022). We are the global market leader and only large-scale Western supplier of high purity grade DCA (a key ingredient for RNA-based medication) in Life Science for pharmaceutical applications (by high purity DCA revenue as of 2022) (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). In cosmetic grade GA, we are globally the second largest supplier (measured by revenue as of 2022) and the only European producer with global coverage (Company assessment based on Roland Berger Report). Our customized products are highly integrated in our key customers’ value chains (sometimes protected by “key supplier” relationships for major products), and we are closely aligned in demand planning and coordination. We have flexible multi-purpose contract manufacturing plants that allow for optimized downtimes between different product campaigns and change-overs. Furthermore, we benefit from six well-invested sites across the globe offering reliability, safety and high product quality. As a result, we have developed a strong reputation of reliable performance in delivering innovative products in large quantities to our clients. We also operate a global site network with assets spanning the U.S., Europe and China, which we believe is unique among Tier 1 Crop Science CDMOs.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Longstanding, Trusted Relationships with Diversified, Blue-Chip Customer Base
Subsubsection Text: We have long-standing relationships with most of our blue-chip customers. We are a trusted partner to major players in the Crop Science market and numerous leading specialties companies in the Life Science and Performance Materials markets rely on our solutions and significant expertise for their products and applications. High customer retention rates serve as a competitive moat against new entrants: For example, in 2021 and 2022, we had an overall average customer retention rate of approximately 98% (based on existing customer revenue over total revenue for the respective year), which illustrates, together with the high rate of contract renewal and lock-in effects, the “stickiness” of our topline in Exclusives. Our average duration of business relationships with our top four customers in Crop Science exceeds 15 years in tenure (based on management estimates between 2020 and 2022) and a number of our Crop Science blue-chip relationships span more than 30 years (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). Together with the high revenue visibility that most of our longer-term contracts in Exclusives provide, our customers’ long-term commitments are supported by a track record of co-investments in production facilities through upfront capital expenditure or top-up pricing over the term of the contract. We supply a multitude of individual products to our top customers, which we believe indicates our customers’ trust in our capabilities and the quality of our varied products. In 2021 and 2022, we supplied more than 10 products for each of our top three customers. 4 ----- Our customer base in particular reflects our established position and depth of integration into their respective value chains, with the top ten customers by revenue across all markets accounting for approximately 60%, based on internal assessments, of our group-wide revenue in the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Our established customer base in our CDMO Crop Science business includes the top five Crop Science majors across all major crop systems in our key end-markets, with whom we work in close cooperation in terms of process development and planning as well as the lifecycle of the project (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). In addition, while agrochemicals are a key end-market for our products, we are diversifying into other applications such as further high-value intermediates within Advanced Intermediates, pharmaceuticals and Specialties. For our Exclusives products in particular, the close customer cooperation enables de-risked investments in growth capex for further capacity and technology expansion through customer contributions (e.g., capex co-investment or ‘takeor-pay’ commitments by customers). Over the last three years, we have established a track record of consistent project wins (at least one major 1 [st] campaign project per year), building upon our deep integration into our customers’ value chains and our reputation of reliability and ability to manage complex processes. As of March 31, 2023, we also had multiple projects in varying ramp-up phases, supporting growth of the business. The growth capex associated with these ramp-up projects mainly targets or has targeted capacity expansion for Exclusives and Specialties across our plants, and production under these projects is expected to ramp-up over the short-term.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Attractive CDMO business model: high visibility, de-risked growth and recurring earnings
Subsubsection Text: For our Exclusives products, we have developed strategic partnerships with well-known companies, including some of the largest global agrochemicals producers, including blue chip customers in our key end-markets. Due to our high level of integration into our customers’ product development and long contract terms for most of our contracts, we have high visibility on the lifecycle and returns on our products. Our long-term contracts often provide for guaranteed volumes in the initial period, contributing to a high contract renewal rate and low customer churn for a large part of our portfolio. Because of our strong market position and customer integration, we also have high visibility into our customers’ future demand and their upcoming product launches. For example, we received customer inquiries from five top Crop Science players for 70% of all active ingredients launched or planned to be launched in the market between 2020 and 2023E (calculated as share of novel active ingredients and advanced/key intermediate launches where we were inquired) and have won projects in novel active ingredients with these players at a success rate of approximately 40% (calculated as the share of projects won if we were inquired). Moreover, our customers in the CDMO business typically contractually agree for new products to either (i) contribute a portion of the capital expenditures related to new product developments and the production line setup, with minimum contract terms providing payback of the capital expenditures incurred directly by us, or (ii) firm take-or-pay agreements with limited capital expenditures contributions upfront. We continue to invest significantly in growth projects to deliver contracted new product wins and in maintenance to safeguard asset reliability. Our disciplined selection criteria in our CDMO business are focused on superior contracts with limited investment periods for growth capex projects where we typically target EBITDA pay-back periods of approximately three years and return rates of approximately 25% IRR secured by binding customer capex or offtake commitments. While this is not achieved in all our projects, we aim to strengthen our product portfolio over time with projects that either match our key criteria or otherwise offer strategic opportunities. We are well positioned to benefit from the ramp-up of contracted growth projects in Kokkola and Pratteln with an existing agreement portfolio featuring ‘take-or-pay’ commitments. For more information, see also “⸺Our _Product Portfolio.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Resilient Top-line Growth and Strong Margins with Significant Future Upside
Subsubsection Text: We have shown our ability to maintain high revenue growth and margin stability, especially within Exclusives and Specialties, driven by new product wins and strong demand in the existing portfolio, while maintaining flexibility to changing market conditions through our ability to partially pass on increasing raw material and energy costs. Most recently, we commissioned a new line of product under a ‘take-or-pay’ contract and secured a new contract in our Exclusives business. Our major project wins over the last four years reflect our consistent track-record of winning and delivering large-scale projects: 5 ----- Source: Company Information (1) Highest annual revenue achieved to date. In addition, our rationalization of our portfolio to focus on high margin and growth products (e.g., DCA, GA for skin care applications) as well as price increases in Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals have further contributed to our successful performance. We have also been able to adjust our business to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic without major impacts on our operations or financial results due to resilient demand from Crop Science and Life Science customers. Driven by our management’s commitment to support high-value products and projects, we have been able to consistently generate stable margins. As a result, our revenue increased at a CAGR of 23.9% from €492.3 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2020 to €755.5 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Revenue growth in 2022 was primarily driven by strong demand in both our product groups across the portfolio supported by higher pricing effects, in particular partial pass-through of increased raw material prices and supply chain costs in our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals product group. Our Adjusted EBITDA has grown at a CAGR of 20.0% from €112.9 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2020 to €162.6 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The significant growth in Adjusted EBITDA in 2022 in particular was due to an increase in pricing resulting in a higher margin for our products from customers in our Exclusives and Specialties business as well as positive pricing effects in our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals business.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Backward-integrated model that enables re-use of by-products and reduction of waste
Subsubsection Text: Increasing operational efficiency is a top priority for us as it provides clear benefits. When these benefits are combined, they create a virtuous cycle by minimizing negative environmental impacts, creating cost advantages in production, driving innovation and enabling our long-term competitiveness. Production processes always result in byproducts. We aim to reuse or commercialize such byproducts wherever feasible and avoid waste wherever possible. To this end, we believe we operate a highly efficient circular economy processes and we eliminate waste by developing highly efficient processes with optimized product yields and reusing materials within production cycles. Besides the environmental and sustainability advantages, this type of closed-loop system also has tangible financial benefits, as it can reduce costs for raw materials and waste treatments. In Pratteln, we are contributing to the creation of a circular economy using a “Verbund System”. This enables highly efficient and sustainable chlorination and sulfonation reactions. Chlorine and sulfur trioxide are produced as primary raw materials and used to manufacture a variety of chlorination and sulfonation reagents. In turn, these are used to produce further downstream intermediates and active ingredients. The HCl and SO2 generated as off-gases are separated, purified and recycled, reused or resold. Finally, our production sites benefit from high supply chain resilience through backward integration of key raw materials and production processes for our Exclusives and Specialties Products (by using our Advanced Intermediates production). In particular, our main multi-purpose plant in Pratteln uses an innovative set-up that offers high efficiency production of Exclusives and Specialties products, based on backwards integration of the key raw materials of chlorine. Together with the supply of large volumes of necessary MCA from our sites in Germany, we can therefore contribute to supply resilience, as we are in control of the relevant production steps and at the same time can manage the direct commercialization of side streams generated in the production processes, which are then sold as Base Chemicals. See “⸺Production Facilities.” We benefit from close proximity to our customers’ main production sites in the Western markets and we focus on developing and 6 ----- maintaining strong logistic capabilities to enable seamless fulfillment and integration in the respective customer’s supply chain. The chart below shows our production site locations around the world and our production capabilities:

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Focus on ESG and sustainability principles
Subsubsection Text: We have made ESG one of our corporate priorities and consider it a key element of our success. Due to the nature of our business and our position as a business partner deeply integrated into our customers’ supply chains, we are aware of the importance of ESG in daily operations as our performance directly translates into the value chain and ESG commitments of our partners. We have underlined our sustainability commitment by committing to seven UN sustainable development goals, signing the ‘UN Global Compact’, ‘Charta der Vielfalt’ and the ‘Responsible Care’ initiative. Our corporate programs are based on external standards and assessments, and we have set up a special team as well as an ESG management tool for implementing and monitoring our ESG measures. In 2022, we became a member of the “Together for Sustainability” initiative, a collaboration of operating chemical companies that are committed to sustainability throughout their value chains. From 2022 on, all our sites will undergo annual audits by Eco-Vadis with the latest ratings conducted in 2022. Furthermore, our holistic approach to ESG is reflected by, among other indicators, our twelve sustainability targets, which comprise seven targets by 2025 and five by 2030, respectively, and by the role of ESG performance in management bonus schemes. In addition, we are focused on our social responsibility and, as a result, strive to offer employees an attractive and inspiring work environment that provides opportunities for individual development and growth. We focus on promoting diversity as well as occupational health and safety as essential components for operational excellence. See “Our Business⸺ESG and Sustainability.”

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Focused, Credible Management Team with Proven Track Record
Subsubsection Text: We have a highly qualified workforce alongside an experienced management team with deep industry experience. Our management team has successfully repositioned CABB as an integrated CDMO platform and led a significant step-up in growth and margin since 2018, effectively managing our continued success during the COVID-19 pandemic. Our demonstrated track record has been achieved by strict contract discipline and a streamlined organizational setup, while simultaneously leveraging efficiencies from OneCABB (which combined our legacy business units into one integrated company to flatten the organizational structure and drive efficiencies across functions) and making further improvements to operational excellence. This has been the basis of the successful transformation of our business, developing a differentiated CDMO position with highly successful year-over-year improvements over the past five years, including developing on our environmental, social and governance practices. 7 ----- We believe our management’s industry knowledge and leadership, combined with their long-term experience, provide us with the skills necessary to continue improving performance and efficiency through a common corporate infrastructure and the implementation of best practices across our network, which constitutes a significant competitive advantage and drives our future. On March 24, 2023, we announced that Thomas H. Ahrens will become the new chief executive officer of CABB Group following Valerie Diele-Braun’s departure. Mr. Ahrens will join CABB on June 1, 2023 and succeed Valerie Diele-Braun after a transition period of a few months. We believe Mr. Ahrens to be an experienced leader who has a positive track record in driving sustainable growth and profitability. Building on his extensive industry expertise, we believe he will strengthen the Group’s position as a premier contract development and manufacturing organization and leading producer of proprietary ingredients for customers in the Life Science and Performance Materials industries.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Deliver excellence in production to optimize profitability
Subsubsection Text: We are focused on further developing our project portfolio and aim to add more high-value projects to our portfolio each year, keeping in line with our historical project win rates. Our established market position in Exclusives serves as the backbone of our strategy by continuously driving resilient growth and margin stability, complemented by high growth in existing niche markets in Specialties and further supported by fundamental market trends. We are dedicated to continue focusing on novel active ingredients and high-value products, expanding our distribution and geographical reach in our Life Science applications and focusing on high-purity and higher margin segments in Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals for attractive contracts with increasing capacity. We aim to further increase our operational excellence by focusing on efficiency, strengthening key account and sales functions, ramp-ups of additional capacities and continuous de-bottlenecking, as well as fostering our commercial excellence by winning new customers from large, less reliable competitors in the MCA business.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Deliver de-risked capacity and technology expansion
Subsubsection Text: We will continue to strengthen our strategic positioning in Exclusives and Specialties by focusing on novel active ingredients and investments in state-of-the-art technologies. We believe that we can benefit from a ramp-up in a number of contracted and already invested projects across Exclusives and Specialties products with contractual ‘take-or-pay’ or exclusivity clauses which are underpinned by a well invested asset base that, as a result, significantly reduces the risks associated with their execution. We expect to additionally benefit from leveraging partial cost pass-through mechanisms in future contracts. Consequently, we believe our business is highly resilient and that the predictable customer demand for our CDMO and other highly specialized products offers high visibility on the underlying product lifecycle and returns for a certain part of the portfolio.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Strong focus on client relationships and varied commercial capabilities
Subsubsection Text: We are dedicated to winning new projects by leveraging our long-standing relationships with our blue chip customer base as well as our know-how and reputation as a trusted Western CDMO Crop Science business partner to accelerate and win new contracts as proven in the past. In addition, we plan to further increase our Specialties revenue through a push of our attractive portfolio to additional geographies and customers expanding the volume of our high margin products. Furthermore, as some of our main customer relationships exceed 15 years, we have established ourselves as a key outsourcing partner with trusted supplier status for our clients worldwide who often return to extend existing projects or to collaborate with us on potential new products. As a result, we have very low customer churn, particularly for our Exclusives and Specialties offering, and our top customers work with us for a multitude of individual products. We will continue to strengthen those long-standing customer relationships by working closely with our customers to meet their volume and specification needs for their existing and new products. We intend to expand our production capacity to meet the growing demand of our key customers, continue to optimize our production processes to share efficiency gains and work closely with them to tailor our production processes to new products. We intend to continue to focus on multinational customers and industry leaders, in an effort to benefit from strong innovation and global market penetration opportunities. By further strengthening our relationships with 8 ----- multinational customers who have leading market positions in their industries, we seek to grow with them as they expand their businesses. The introduction of OneCABB has allowed us to further streamline our customers primary points of contact with us and will, we believe, contribute to even stronger customer relationships.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Develop and further expand into additional markets
Subsubsection Text: We remain focused on targeted capacity expansion to capture growing demand and additional production volumes that our customers seek to outsource to us, in line with new growth projects of our customers. Jayhawk, located in the United States, produces customized agricultural, pharmaceutical and specialty chemicals and continues to offer the potential for standalone growth from its existing pipeline portfolio and production of new products, as well as proximity to customers in the Americas. In addition, we believe our Pratteln and Kokkola sites have benefited from cooperation with Jayhawk due to the fact that we can offer various technologies and additional geographies and act in an agile manner according to their needs. By focusing on high quality services, we plan to further capture rising needs in markets which deliver higher margin profiles, for example, pharma, personal care, nutrition and performance materials. This will allow us to capitalize our operating leverage and efficiency gains by, for example, planning to hold plant costs relatively stable despite topline growth. We continue to focus on high capacity utilization as the key success factor for sustainable development, as well as optimized logistics solutions such as the addition of our leased titanium fleet of railcars which will allow for the delivery of more product with fewer railcars due to its lower weight and better loading factor.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Maintain focus on profitability and cash flow
Subsubsection Text: We will continue to focus on improving our profitability through cost savings and efficiency enhancements where possible, such as investments in energy saving measures, footprint optimization and automatization. We believe that there is an ongoing potential for efficiency measures through continuous optimization of our manufacturing processes and recycling streams. We intend to seek to further improve cash flow generation by maximizing the utilization of our production facilities and expanding our production capacity (e.g., in Kokkola and Jayhawk), as well as continuing investments for maintenance to preserve our well-maintained asset base. At the same time, we plan to remain disciplined in our growth capital expenditure projects by securing customers’ longer-term volume commitments in advance and co-investments in the form of upfront capital expenditure or top-up pricing over the terms of customers’ contracts.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Maintain health, safety and environmental excellence
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to a strategy of ESG and sustainability based on environmentally responsible manufacturing processes and ensuring the health and safety of our employees. We aim to benefit from the strong collaboration on ESG and sustainability with customers and industry platforms to improve our sustainability footprint while capitalizing on operating efficiencies. The strong collaboration on ESG in negotiations is based on joint improvement programs further developing our green footprint in our customers’ value chain which, in turn, also contributes to operational efficiencies. Our production facilities in Pratteln and Gersthofen play a significant role in our effort to conserve energy and resources and to reduce emissions and waste. We believe measuring ourselves at a high standard with respect to ESG and sustainability contributes not only to environmental and societal goals but also makes us an even more attractive partner to our business partners in their selection of partners within their value chain. See “Our Business⸺ESG and Sustainability.” 9 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The following is a summary of the activities we are currently undertaking in pursuit of these opportunities:

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Our business has its origins in the chemical production activities of Hoechst AG, which originally commissioned our production facility in Gersthofen, Germany, in 1905 as well as our production facility in Knapsack, Germany, in 1949. In 1997, the Hoechst Specialty Chemicals business was acquired by Clariant. Several years later, in 2003, the CABB Group GmbH was founded as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Clariant before being acquired by an Investment Management in 2005 and then by AXA Private Equity in the following year. In 2007, we acquired SF Chem, including our production facility in Pratteln, Switzerland, which allowed us to expand into contract manufacturing. In 2011, we were acquired by Bridgepoint; that same year we acquired KemFine from 3i and commenced production at our facility in Kokkola, Finland, to further expand our contract manufacturing capabilities. In 2013, we expanded our footprint to Asia through the establishment of a joint venture with Jining Jinwei Gold Power to acquire Jinwei Huasheng Chemicals. We hold a 67% stake in the joint venture entity CABB-Jinwei Specialty Chemicals (Jining) Co., Ltd. In 2014, we were acquired by the Permira Funds and have since invested in an electrolysis plant in Pratteln, capacity expansions and de-bottlenecking in most facilities as well as in a new wastewater facility in China. In 2019, we acquired Evonik Jayhawk Fine Chemicals Corporation, one of the leading fine chemicals companies in the U.S., from Evonik Industries AG. In 2021, we introduced OneCABB, which combined our legacy business units into one integrated company to flatten the organizational structure and drive efficiencies across functions.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Permira is a global investment firm that backs successful businesses with growth ambitions. Founded in 1985, the firm advises funds with total assets under management of €77 billion and makes long-term majority and minority investments. The Permira Funds have made approximately 300 private equity investments in four key sectors: technology, consumer, healthcare and services. Permira employs over 450 people in 15 offices across Europe, North America, and Asia.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We intend to use the proceeds from the issue of the Notes, together with cash on balance sheet, to (i) redeem the Existing Notes in full (including paying the accrued and unpaid interest), (ii) pay the applicable redemption premium for the Existing Notes, (iii) pay related fees and expenses. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.” On or about the Issue Date, the Issuer will redeem and satisfy and discharge all of the Existing Notes by paying the relevant redemption price for each of the Existing Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest thereon to the date of redemption. 10 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: On April 20, 2023, we entered into our new senior secured revolving credit facility in the amount of €110 million which is not expected to be utilized at the Issue Date. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.” We refer to the Offering, the Refinancing, including the redemption of the Existing Notes, the entry into the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and the application of the use of proceeds as set out in the section “Use of _Proceeds” as the “Transactions.” Please see “Use of Proceeds,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: On March 14, 2023, we announced that Valerie Diele-Braun, who currently serves as the Chief Executive Officer of CABB Group, will step down from her position after the arrival and transition period to the new designated CEO Thomas H. Ahrens. On March 24, 2023, we announced that Thomas H. Ahrens will become the new chief executive officer of CABB Group. Mr. Ahrens will join CABB on June 1, 2023 and succeed Valerie Diele-Braun after a transition period of a few months. See “Management.”

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: _The unaudited preliminary financial results for the periods presented below are derived from our accounting records. This information has neither been audited, verified, reviewed or is subject to any procedures by any external auditors nor has it been approved by our Board of Directors. Accordingly, you should not place undue reliance on such unaudited preliminary financial results, and no opinion or any other form of assurance is provided with respect thereto. Our unaudited preliminary financial results are based upon a number of assumptions and judgments that are subject to inherent uncertainties and are subject to review, change and adjustment in the course of preparation of our consolidated financial statements, and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results for the periods presented. Although we believe the management estimates and unaudited preliminary financial information and the assumptions on which they are based to be reasonable, our preliminary financial results are subject to change, and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2023. See “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” for a discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance and results of operation._ Based on preliminary results derived from unaudited management monthly accounts and other information currently available, we estimate that our revenue for the three months ended March 31, 2023 increased to approximately €207.1 million from €181.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022, representing an estimated increase of approximately 14.0% compared to the same period in 2022. This increase was primarily driven by price increases in both product groups ‘Exclusives and Specialties’ as well as ‘Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals.’ We estimate that our Adjusted EBITDA for the three months ended March 31, 2023 increased to approximately €55.2 million from €33.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022, representing an estimated increase of approximately 63.3% compared to the same period in 2022. This increase was primarily due to the pricing driven top line growth which offset the increases in variable and fix costs compared to the three months ended 31 March 2022. For the financial year ended December 31, 2023, we expect our Adjusted EBITDA to grow in the low single-digit percentage range primarily due to continued growth in Exclusives and Specialties as well as Advanced Intermediates, compensated by an expected normalization of the caustic soda price. 11 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: This summary highlights selected information about us and the Offering contained in this Offering Memorandum. This summary is not complete and does not contain all the information you should consider before investing in the Notes. The following summary should be read in conjunction with, and the following summary is qualified in its entirety by, the more detailed information included in this Offering Memorandum, including our Consolidated Financial Statements. You should read carefully the entire Offering Memorandum to understand our business, the nature and terms of the Notes and the tax and other considerations which are important to your decision to invest in the Notes, including the risks discussed under the captions “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements.”

Section Title: CORPORATE STRUCTURE AND CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The following chart shows a simplified summary of our corporate and financing structure as of the date of this Offering Memorandum adjusted to give effect to the Transactions. The chart does not include all of our subsidiaries or all the debt obligations thereof. For a summary of the debt obligations identified in this diagram, please refer to the sections entitled “Description of the Notes,”, “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Capitalization.” (1) As of March 31, 2023, Permira beneficially owned, directly or indirectly through intermediate holding companies, 85.82% of the ordinary share capital of Monitchem Holdco 1 S.à r.l. and certain employees and members of management and the advisory board indirectly held 14.18% of the ordinary share capital of Monitchem Holdco 1 S.à r.l through a management equity participation program. See “Certain _Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Management Equity Participation Program.”_ 12 ----- (2) In this Offering Memorandum, we present the consolidated annual financial statements of Monitchem Holdco 2 S.A., for the financial years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively. Monitchem Holdco 2 S.A. is not a member of the restricted group (the “Restricted Group”) subject to the covenants under the Indenture, which comprise the Issuer and the Issuer’s restricted subsidiaries, and will not guarantee the Notes. On a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions and the application of the proceeds therefrom, the only material assets of Monitchem Holdco 2 S.A. will be its equity ownership in the Issuer. References to the “Group” are to Monitchem Holdco 2 S.A. and its subsidiaries, unless the context requires otherwise. On June 26, 2014, Monitchem Holdco 2 S.A. and the Issuer entered into the Senior Notes Proceeds Loan Agreement. The Senior Notes Proceeds Loan Agreement will be cancelled and the Senior Notes Proceeds Loan will be repaid in connection with the redemption of the Existing Senior Notes. (3) As part of the Group’s corporate strategy, Monitchem HoldCo 2 S.A. and the Issuer may in the future change their legal form into a German limited liability company (Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung) and migrate their effective place of management from Luxembourg to Germany (the “Migration”). (4)  On October 7, 2019, Monitchem Holdco 2 S.A. issued €150,000,000 aggregate principal amount of its 9.500% senior notes due 2026 (the “Existing Senior Notes”). The Existing Senior Notes are expected to be redeemed in full in connection with the Transactions. (5) On October 7, 2019, the Issuer issued €315,000,000 aggregate principal amount of its 5.250% senior secured fixed rate notes due 2025 (the “Existing Senior Secured Fixed Rate Notes”) and €175,000,000 aggregate principal amount of its senior secured floating rate notes due 2025 (the “Existing Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes” and, together with the Existing Senior Secured Fixed Rate Notes, the “Existing Senior Secured Notes” and, together with the Existing Senior Notes, the “Existing Notes”). The Existing Senior Secured Notes are expected to be redeemed in full in connection with the Transactions. The Notes will be the Issuer’s general, senior obligations and will rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including obligations under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement (as defined herein), certain cash management obligations, if any, and certain hedging obligations, if any, and rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, if any. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis (the “Notes Guarantees” and each, a “Notes Guarantee”) (i) on or about the Issue Date, by CABB Group GmbH and (ii) within 120 days of the Issue Date, by the Subsidiary Guarantors (as defined herein) (each a “Guarantor” and together, the “Guarantors”). The Notes Guarantee issued by each Guarantor will rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of that Guarantor that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Notes Guarantee (including indebtedness incurred under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations) and rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Notes Guarantee, if any. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of the enforcement of the security, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral and distressed disposals only after obligations under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and certain super-senior hedging and cash management obligations have been repaid in full. See “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.”_ (6) On April 20, 2023, CABB Group GmbH, as borrower and guarantor and the Issuer, as guarantor, entered into the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement which provides for the €110 million New Revolving Credit Facility. We expect that the New Revolving Credit Facility will be undrawn on the Issue Date. The New Revolving Credit Facility will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the same entities that guarantee the Notes and will be secured on a first priority basis over the same collateral securing the Notes and certain hedging and cash management obligations. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement.” (7) As of and for the financial year ended December 31, 2022, the Guarantors represented 99.5% of Adjusted EBITDA (disregarding the EBITDA of any member of the Group that generates negative EBITDA). 13 -----

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes ........................... The Notes will:
Subsubsection Text: - be general senior obligations of the Issuer; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the obligations of the Issuer under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and certain cash management and hedging obligations; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness or obligation of the Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness or obligation; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Issuer’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes, including obligations to trade creditors.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Notes Guarantees ................................. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis (i) on the Issue Date, by
Subsubsection Text: CABB Group GmbH, and (ii) within 120 days of the Issue Date, by the Subsidiary Guarantors (collectively, the “Notes Guarantees”). The Notes Guarantees will be subject to contractual and legal limitations and may be released under certain circumstances. See “Certain _Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ As of and for the financial year ended December 31, 2022, the Guarantors represented 99.5% of the Adjusted EBITDA (disregarding the EBITDA of any member of the Group that generates negative EBITDA).

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes Guarantees ....... The Notes Guarantee of each Guarantor will:
Subsubsection Text: - be a general senior obligation of that Guarantor; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Notes Guarantee, including that Guarantor’s obligations under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and certain cash management obligations, if any and certain hedging obligations, if any; - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Notes Guarantee; 15 ----- - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness or obligation of that Guarantor that is secured by property or assets that do not secure such Notes Guarantee, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such other indebtedness or obligation; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness, including obligations to trade creditors, of the subsidiaries of such Guarantor that are Notes Guarantors. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and may be subject to release under certain circumstances. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor _Agreement” and “Description of the Notes—The Note Guarantees.”_

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Security, Enforcement of Security ..... On or about the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles,
Subsubsection Text: certain perfection requirements and the terms of the security documents, the Notes will be secured by the following first priority security interests: - a German law governed share pledge granted by the Issuer over its shares in CABB Group GmbH; - a Luxembourg law governed security agreement granted by the Issuer over any material structural intercompany loan receivables owed to it by any member of the Group; - a German law governed security agreement granted by CABB Group GmbH over any material structural intercompany loan receivables owed to it by any member of the Group; and - a Luxembourg law governed security agreement granted by the Issuer over any material bank accounts of the Issuer located in Luxembourg, (collectively, the “Issue Date Collateral”). The Indenture will provide that, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Issuer will be required to cause, within 120 days of the Issue Date, and subject to certain perfection requirements and the terms of the security documents, the Notes to be secured by the following first priority security interests: - a German law governed share pledge granted by CABB Holding GmbH over its shares in CABB GmbH; - a Swiss law governed share pledge granted by CABB Europe GmbH over its shares in CABB AG; - a Finnish law governed share pledge granted by CABB Finland Oy over its shares in CABB Oy; - a New York law governed share pledge granted by Kansas HoldCo 1, Inc. over its shares in Jayhawk Fine Chemicals Corporation; and - a New York law governed all asset security collateral agreement granted by Jayhawk Fine Chemicals Corporation over its assets (subject to customary exclusions, which shall include, without limitation, real estate and intellectual property), 16 ----- (collectively, the “Post-Issue Date Collateral”, and, together with the Issue Date Collateral, the collectively, the “Collateral”). The assets that comprise the Collateral will also secure on a first priority basis, the New Revolving Credit Facility and may also secure certain future Indebtedness (including any Additional Notes). Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the holders of Notes will only receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral after the lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, counterparties to certain super priority hedging and cash management obligations (if any), the Security Agent, any receiver and certain creditor representatives have been repaid in full. See “Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.”_ The security interests in the Collateral may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. See “Description of the Notes—Security,” “Certain _Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes.”_ The security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Notes—Security.”_

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Use of Proceeds .................................... The gross proceeds from the offering of the Notes, together with cash on
Subsubsection Text: balance sheet, will be used to (i) redeem the Existing Notes in full (including paying the accrued and unpaid interest), (ii) pay the applicable redemption premium for the Existing Notes, and (iii) pay related fees and expenses.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Floating Rate Notes ............................... The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Floating Rate Notes at any time on or after May 1, 2024 at the redemption prices as described under “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” At any time prior to May 1, 2024, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Floating Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption plus a “make-whole” premium, as described under “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” Fixed Rate Notes ................................... The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Fixed Rate Notes at any time on or after May 1, 2025 at the redemption prices as described under “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” At any time prior to May 1, 2025, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Fixed Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption plus a “make-whole” premium, as described under “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” At any time prior to May 1, 2025, the Issuer may on one or more occasions redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes, using the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to 108.75% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the 17 ----- date of redemption; provided that at least 50% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes remains outstanding after the redemption. At any time prior to May 1, 2025, the Issuer may redeem, during each 12-month period commencing on the Issue Date, up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes outstanding at its option, from time to time, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Additional Amounts; Tax Redemption .......................................... Any payments made by or on behalf of either Issuer or any Guarantor in
Subsubsection Text: respect of the Notes or with respect to any Notes Guarantee will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes in any relevant taxing jurisdiction unless required by law. Subject to certain exceptions and limitations, if either the Issuer, any Guarantor or the paying agent is required by law to withhold or deduct such taxes with respect to a payment on any Note, the Issuer or such Guarantor will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by each holder after such withholding is not less than the amount that would have been received in the absence of the withholding. If certain changes in the law of any relevant taxing jurisdiction become effective after the issuance of the Notes that would impose withholding taxes or other deductions on the payments on the Notes, and would require the Issuer or any Guarantor to pay additional amounts (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes”), the Issuer or any Guarantor may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Change of Control ............................... Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuer
Subsubsection Text: may be required to make an offer to purchase the outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of purchase. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred on one occasion if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded as a result of such event. See “Description of the Notes.”

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Certain Covenants ............................... The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the Issuer
Subsubsection Text: and its restricted subsidiaries, to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain investments; - make certain other restricted payments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of the Issuer’s subsidiaries to pay dividends; - transfer or sell certain assets; - merge or consolidate with other entities; 18 ----- - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; - impair the security interests created for the benefit of the holders of the Notes; and - (in case of the Issuer only) engage in activities other than certain permitted holding company activities. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if the Notes obtain and maintain an investment-grade rating. Each of the covenants in the Indenture will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain _Covenants.”_

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Transfer Restrictions ........................... The Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been, and will not be,
Subsubsection Text: registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Notice to Prospective U.S. Investors,” “Notice to Certain _European Investors” and “Notice to Residents of Canada.” We have not_ agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Notes under the securities laws in any jurisdiction (including by way of an exchange offer).

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Original Issue Discount ....................... Because the Floating Rate Notes will be issued with original issue
Subsubsection Text: discount (“OID”),, U.S. holders of Floating Rate Notes (as defined under “Taxation—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations”) generally will be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) on an annual basis under a constant yield accrual method regardless of their regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. As a result, U.S. holders of Floating Rate Notes will generally include any OID in income in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such income. See “Taxation—Certain U.S. Federal _Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount.”_

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: No Established Market for the Notes ..................................................... The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no
Subsubsection Text: established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Listing ................................................... Application will be made to admit the Notes to listing on the Securities
Subsubsection Text: Official List of the LuxSE, without admission to trading on one of the securities markets operated by the LuxSE.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Governing Law .................................... The Indenture, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be governed by
Subsubsection Text: the laws of the State of New York. For the avoidance of doubt, the provisions of articles 470-1 to 470-19 of the Luxembourg act dated August 10, 1915 on commercial companies, as amended are not applicable to the Notes. The Intercreditor Agreement and the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement will be governed by English law. The security documents will be governed by the applicable law of the jurisdiction under which the security interests are granted.

Subsubsection Text: _The Issuer is a holding company and is not expected to engage in any activities other than those related to the Transactions. All historical financial information of the Group included in this Offering Memorandum is that of Monitchem Holdco 2 S.A. (the direct holding company of the Issuer) and its consolidated subsidiaries. Certain of the following tables present the Group’s summary financial information and should be read in conjunction with the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, which are all reproduced elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and the section entitled “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.” The Audited Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared in accordance with IFRS and were audited by KPMG Luxembourg which issued an unqualified audit opinion for each year. The information below is not necessarily indicative of the results of future operations. We present below certain non-IFRS financial measures and ratios that are not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS, including Reported EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA, and certain leverage and coverage ratios, among others. There can be no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. The non-IFRS financial measures are not measurements of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measure of performance derived in accordance with IFRS.
