The non-IFRS financial measures as presented in this Offering Memorandum may differ from and may not be comparable to similarly titled financial measures used by other companies, and “Reported EBITDA” and “Adjusted EBITDA” differ from “Consolidated EBITDA” contained in the section “Description of the Notes” of this Offering Memorandum and the Indenture. The non-IFRS financial measures may not give an accurate or complete picture of our financial condition or results of operations for the periods presented and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” The historical financial information below is not necessarily indicative of results of future operations and should be read in conjunction with “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Selected Consolidated Financial Information,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, which are included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Industry in Which We Operate
Subsubsection Title: Economic downturns or worsening global economic conditions may adversely impact our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is affected by changes in the general economic conditions of the industries and market segments in which we sell our products, including, in particular, the Crop Science (e.g., herbicides, fungicides, insecticides and other livestock and crop protection products) and Life Science (e.g., pharma, personal care, nutrition, fragrances and flavor applications) markets, as well as the market for Performance Materials (e.g., curatives in epoxies, polyimides, polyesters and other resin systems used for electronic components, semiconductors and for composites, fibers, films, and foams that provide heat and electrical resistance). Any change in demand or in the application of our products within these end-markets or the failure to accurately predict or adapt to future market trends may negatively impact our sales and margins and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Based on our internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of all our products were used in the Crop Science market in 2022 (measured as a percentage of revenues). Historically, the Crop Science market has experienced seasonal declines due to, among other things, decreasing crop commodity prices and subsequently lower net cash income for farmers, lower pest threats which negatively affects demand for pesticides, trade restrictions, inclement long-term weather conditions and economic recession in production markets such as in Brazil. While the market for Crop Science has grown each year for the past three years, any future market trends are inherently uncertain and any declines in demand for Crop Science (as well as in any other end-market) could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. This industry is driven by structural long-term trends, such as population growth combined with an increasing calorie intake per capita, in particular in emerging markets, and decreasing arable land per capita. Furthermore, over the past decades, Crop Science products have become increasingly complex and newer products are required to replace old ones, driven by either regulatory requirements or the search for more effective formulations (Roland Berger Report, Company Information) and we may not be successful in offering the products required by our customers. See also “⸺Risks Related to Our Business⸺We are dependent on a small number of Customers and _Key Products for a significant portion of our revenue.”_ In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 20% of our products were used in the Life Science market (measured as a percentage of revenues). This market is affected by several long-term trends, including an aging population driving an increase in chronic diseases and leading to more spending on, and demand for, pharmaceutical and personal care products, as well as a growing middle class that is leading to an increasing sedentary lifestyle (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). However, innovations and technological progress in the pharmaceutical industry, including production processes of pharmaceutical products, as well as changes in access to medical care, changes in the ability of end-customers to pay for medical care and regulatory approval of certain medical therapies by public health authorities such as the FDA (as defined below), can affect demand for our products in the Life Science market and we may not be successful in offering the products required by our customers. Furthermore, changes in general economic conditions directly impact consumer confidence and spending as well as the general business climate and levels of business investment. This may directly affect our customers in the food, personal care and cosmetics industries and ultimately our business, 25 ----- financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. See also “⸺Risks Related to Our Business⸺We are _dependent on a small number of Customers and Key Products for a significant portion of our revenue.”_ Finally, the growth of the Performance Materials market is expected to correlate to the general economic conditions measured by GDP. In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 15% our products were used in the Performance Materials market (measured as a percentage of revenues). Declines in the electronics and semiconductors end-markets or specific industrial and infrastructure applications (e.g. hot air filtration), or other disruptions affecting these niche applications could have a material adverse effect on the demand for our Performance Materials products and therefore on our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows. Similarly, other products, such as caustic soda, that are generated as by-products from our Exclusives and Advanced Intermediates production lines, might be affected by similar declines in their respective end-markets or changes in supply and demand balances. For example, the market price of some of our products, e.g. caustic soda, and raw materials we use in our production declined in 2020 and 2021, thereby negatively impacting the contribution of some of our products to profitability for the financial years 2020 and 2021, but subsequently significantly increased in 2022 and, in the case of caustic soda, reached an all-time high. However, the market price for some our products, including caustic soda, is expected to normalize (approximately €400-600/t (WE spot rate)) and may be exposed to future fluctuations due to macro-economic or other risks which could affect the pricing in Base Chemicals and Advanced Intermediates. Continued elevated levels of political and economic uncertainty, increased interest rates, rising inflation, price volatility and shortages in raw materials and energy, increased transportation costs and climate chaos could have unpredictable consequences and may lead to a global economic downturn, potentially affecting demand for all our products. In addition, in Europe, past and potential future changes to monetary policy, continuing doubts about the future of the Eurozone, insufficient deleveraging in the private and public sectors and an elevated level of political instability could adversely affect our operations. In the United States, uncertainties associated with policies adverse to international trade implemented in recent years (for example with China), both nationally and internationally, have led to market volatility and political uncertainty. Also, any imposition of tariffs as a result of economic or political tensions may affect, for example, costs for obtaining raw materials necessary to our business. Should such developments arise again and lead to a global economic downturn, it may reduce demand for goods that incorporate our products and, in turn, our customers’ demand for our products. All of the above could negatively impact our sales and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Industry in Which We Operate
Subsubsection Title: The Russia-Ukraine conflict and the resulting sanctions and measures taken against Russia have had and may have, and those that may be taken against any other countries in the future may have, further adverse material effects on the global economy, energy supplies and prices, and may have severe adverse effects on the operations of energy-intensive sectors (e.g., heavy industry, chemical manufacturers, metallurgy, pharma, etc.).
Subsubsection Text: Geopolitical tensions, including but not limited to, tensions between Russia and its neighboring countries, including Ukraine, Poland and the Baltic countries, tensions between China and the United States or acts of terrorism, could also negatively affect the demand for and supply of our merchandise. In late February 2022, Russian military forces launched a significant military action against Ukraine, which has resulted in sustained conflict and disruption in the region. We do not have any direct revenue exposure to Russia or Ukraine; however, we are aware that some of our customers subsequently distribute our products or incorporate our products into the production of their goods which, in certain circumstances, are distributed, and may continue to be distributed in the future, into Russia or Ukraine in reliance upon exemptions from sanctions in the crop protection and pharmaceuticals markets. To date we have not experienced any material disruption to our operations, however, the length, impact and outcome of the ongoing military conflict in Ukraine is highly unpredictable. This conflict has led to significant market and other disruptions, including significant volatility in energy and other commodity prices, financial markets, supply chain disruptions and changes in consumer or purchaser preferences, as well as increases in cyberattacks and espionage. See “⸺Economic downturns or worsening global economic conditions _may adversely impact our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows.”_ Russia’s annexation of Crimea and subsequent military action against Ukraine have led to sanctions being levied by the United States, the European Union, the United Kingdom, Canada, Switzerland, Japan and other countries against Russia, Belarus, the Crimea, Zaporizhzhia and Kherson regions of Ukraine, the so-called Donetsk People’s Republic and the so-called Luhansk People’s Republic, including, among others, the removal of certain Russian 26 ----- financial institutions from the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT) payment system, which can significantly hinder the ability to transfer funds in and out of Russia. The situation is rapidly evolving as a result of the conflict in Ukraine, and the United States, the European Union, the United Kingdom and other countries or jurisdictions may implement additional sanctions, export controls or other measures against Russia or other countries, regions, officials, individuals or industries in the respective territories. Such sanctions and other measures, as well as any potential responses from Russia or other countries to such sanctions, tensions and military actions, has adversely affected the global economy and financial markets and could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “⸺Risks Relating to Legal Matters⸺We must _comply with foreign trade laws, sanctions, anti-bribery, anti-trust, anti-money laundering and anti-corruption laws across the jurisdictions in which we operate.”_ We are actively monitoring the situation in Ukraine, including the increase in energy prices associated therewith, and are assessing its impact on our business. We have no way to predict the progress or outcome of the conflict in Ukraine or its impacts in Ukraine, Russia or Belarus as the conflict and any resulting government reactions are rapidly developing and beyond our control. The extent and duration of the military action, sanctions and resulting market disruptions could be significant and could potentially have substantial impact on the global economy and our business for an unknown period of time. In addition, evolving policy dispute between China and the United States and other international communities may result in sanctions and other measures against China in the future, which may adversely impact our business. An escalation of trade tensions between the countries we operate in and China, including if China were to, or is perceived to, provide support to Russia in the war in Ukraine or to circumvent economic sanctions imposed against Russia and its allies, may result in sanctions from the United States and the other countries we operate in against China and its constituents. To the extent such sanctions are put in place, our operations in China (including operations of our joint venture in China) may be significantly restricted. Moreover, such sanctions may also potentially result in the loss of business from our top customers, suppliers, distributors and/or other counterparts if they impose restrictions on our dealings with such parties as where, for example, such parties are owned or controlled by or otherwise affiliated with one or more Chinese person or entity. Any of the abovementioned factors could affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Any such disruptions may also magnify the impact of other risks described in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Industry in Which We Operate
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to stringent environmental, health and safety laws and regulations across multiple jurisdictions. We are highly regulated and may incur significant costs to maintain compliance with, or address liabilities under, environmental, health and safety laws and regulations applicable to our business.
Subsubsection Text: The chemical industry is subject to increasingly stringent environmental laws and regulations in all of the jurisdictions in which we operate or do business, including requirements under governing licenses and permits with regard to air emissions (e.g. CO2 and NOx emissions reduction requirements), energy efficiency (e.g. energy usage reduction), water discharge, the use, management, storage, treatment, transportation and disposal of waste and other materials, the protection and restoration of plants, wildlife, natural resources and public health and safety, product safety and content, the investigation and remediation of contaminated land, and worker- and product-related health and safety, as well as numerous related reporting and record keeping requirements. We are required to comply with environmental, health and safety laws and regulations in relation to our production and distribution processes, and the relevant regulatory authorities carry out regular inspections to ascertain our compliance with applicable laws, regulations and permits. The demands of compliance may require us to incur substantial costs, including capital requirements, clean-up costs, fines or penalties, and/or may restrict our ability to conduct our operations or to do so profitably, and, therefore, could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations. Failure to comply with applicable laws and regulations may also lead to public reprimand, fines or other sanctions, loss of ability to operate and/or sell within certain jurisdictions and damage to our goodwill and reputation and could materially affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We cannot ensure that we will in the future be able to obtain and finance all permits which we require for our business operations. Such failure or any violation of the terms and conditions of such permits, permitting delays or revocation of existing permits could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We also cannot ensure whether or not future administrative action, laws, regulations, international treaties or policies will ban or restrict the usage of some of our products or their respective ingredients or substances in the 27 ----- future. For example, in early 2023, the French food safety authority ANSES initiated a procedure to withdraw authorization of the main uses of plant protection products containing the active substance S-Metolachlor (SMOC), one of our products, because of groundwater pollution and the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) published a restriction proposal on per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) that would effectively ban all forms of PFAS currently in use, apart from active ingredients in medicines, pesticides and biocidal substances. Although France’s ban on SMOC would have a limited impact on our business and although we are closely monitoring further policy measures as well as legal and administrative actions, we cannot exclude with certainty whether the European Union or other countries will adopt further restrictions on SMOC. Any ban on our products or their respective ingredients or substances or any ban on the exportation of such products could impact our operations, including the closure of production lines in our facilities where they have been specifically tailored for the production of a certain product, and/or our business partners’ value chain and could require additional costs associated with internal restructurings, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. See also “⸺Risks Relating to Legal Matters⸺We must _comply with foreign trade laws, sanctions, anti-bribery, anti-trust, anti-money laundering and anti-corruption laws across the jurisdictions in which we operate and “⸺We are subject to risks from legal and arbitration proceedings, including litigation related expenses and/or reputational damage, among other losses, which could harm our business.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Industry in Which We Operate
Subsubsection Title: Competition in our markets may adversely affect our market share, margins and overall profitability.
Subsubsection Text: Our industry is competitive and we face competition from several CDMO producers for our Exclusives products, as well as competition from other large international chemical manufacturers and smaller regional competitors for other parts of our business. We may face increased competition in the future from other potential new entrants in our markets. Competition is based on several key criteria, including technology and technological capabilities, product quality, proprietary technologies and know-how, innovation and performance, production capacity, attractive pricing, geography, security, speed of supply and responsiveness to product development in cooperation with customers. Some of our existing competitors are, and potential future competitors may be, larger than we are (e.g., by revenue or geographical coverage), may have greater financial resources and may also be able to maintain significantly greater operating and financial flexibility than we do. As a result, these competitors may be able to better withstand changes in conditions within our industry, fluctuations in the prices of raw materials and energy and changes in general economic conditions. Additionally, competitors’ pricing decisions could compel us to lower our prices or lead to loss of customers or products and, as a consequence, additional costs for investments into replacement products and/or internal restructurings, which could adversely affect our sales, margins and profitability. See “Risks Related to Our Business⸺We are dependent on a small number of customers and Key Products for a _significant portion of our revenue.”_ Further, our competitors may undertake to expand their production capacity, which could lead to a shift in supply and negative pricing impacts on our products. Our ability to maintain or increase our profitability is, and will continue to be, dependent upon our ability to offset decreases in the prices and margins of our products by improving production efficiency and volume, focusing on higher margin products and improving efficiency of operations through innovation. If we are unable to do so or to otherwise maintain our competitive position, we could lose a portion of our market share to our competitors.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Industry in Which We Operate
Subsubsection Title: Changes in the agricultural and certain other policies of governments and international organizations may adversely impact the Crop Science industry and prove unfavorable to us.
Subsubsection Text: The policies of governments and international organizations may affect the income available to growers to purchase Crop Science products used in agricultural production. In subsidized markets such as the United States, Europe and certain markets in Asia, including Japan, reduction of subsidies to growers may inhibit the growth of markets for products used in agriculture. In addition, changes in governmental policies that impact agriculture may similarly inhibit the growth of markets for products used in agriculture. Specifically, government programs that create incentives for farmers (for example, the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard) may be modified or discontinued. However, it is difficult to predict accurately whether, and if so when, such changes will occur. Should such changes occur, we may experience decreased demand for our products, which would adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We expect that the policies of governments and international organizations will continue to affect the planting choices made by growers as well as the subsidies available to growers to purchase products used in agriculture and, accordingly, the results of our operations in the agriculture industry. 28 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Industry in Which We Operate
Subsubsection Title: The spread of the 2019 coronavirus (“COVID-19”) has had, and the outbreak of another infectious disease or other serious public health concern around the world could have, a negative impact on economies, financial markets and business activities.
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the outbreak of COVID-19 in late 2019 and early 2020 and its spread into numerous countries across the globe, governmental authorities have imposed, and may in the future continue to impose, quarantine zones or lockdowns nationally or on certain cities and regions, all of which have significantly impacted and could continue to impact international, national and regional economic development. Governmental restrictions as well as concerns for the health of employees or confirmed infection cases in our production plants worldwide have caused in the past and may cause in the future, temporary full or partial plant shutdowns and increased costs for protective measures such as staggered schedules, cleaning costs and costs for protective equipment. Uncertainty regarding future developments remains high and there are risks of future supply chain disruptions, increased prices and unavailability of raw materials, production shutdowns, declining demand for our products or problems with shipping products internationally, that could result in higher costs of our products. Furthermore, demand for certain products may fluctuate in the future, negatively affecting our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. The Company has not experienced any material negative impact from COVID-19 with respect to customer demand in the Crop Science and Life Science industries or any significant cancellation of contracts or confirmed orders from our customers. However, some of our plants, such as Jayhawk in the United States, have experienced temporary full or partial shutdowns due to a rise in number of infections and our plants may experience such shutdowns in the future. The extent of the adverse impact of an infectious disease or other serious public health concern, including the COVID-19 pandemic, on the global economy and markets as well as on our business, operations and financial results is difficult to predict. Such impacts will depend on the measures taken to limit the spread and counter its impact and on the size and effectiveness of the compensating measures taken by governments, as well as how quickly and to what extent normal economic and operating conditions can resume. Failure to manage the risks mentioned above and other risks related to an outbreak of an infectious disease (or a new mutation of an existing infectious disease) or other serious public health concern could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on a small number of Customers and Key Products for a significant portion of our revenue.
Subsubsection Text: We derive a substantial portion of our revenue from several large customers and key products and the loss of any such customer or key product would negatively impact our operations. For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, based on internal assessments, our top ten customers across all markets accounted for approximately 60% of our total revenue. Our top 5 Exclusives products accounted for approximately 40% of our Exclusives and Specialties revenue in the financial year ended December 31, 2022 and our top 5 Specialties products generated approximately 15% of our Exclusives and Specialties revenue in the same period. Similarly, our top 5 Advanced Intermediates products generated approximately 60% of our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals revenue in the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Our inability to maintain our customer relationships with key customers or otherwise retain their business at current levels could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. This applies across almost all our product groups. We may lose customers or key products because of, among other things, industry consolidation, customer dissatisfaction, competition, our customers’ products becoming obsolete, product quality and impurity concerns or customers finding cheaper alternative products. Our sales would be adversely affected if customers who currently outsource manufacturing of certain products to us decide to source such products internally or with one of our competitors. For example, one of our customers has decided not to renew a supply contract for a key product that is due to expire in 2024, which generated a mid single digit percentage of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022. In addition, since certain of our products are difficult and expensive to transport over long distances, if local or regional customers were no longer to buy such products, we may encounter difficulties in finding other customers in the same area, which could lead to a decrease in our sales. Furthermore, we supply some of our customers, particularly for our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals, without formal agreements in the open market, which results in lower switching costs for our customers and reduces our ability to predict our sales to such customers in the long-term. 29 ----- Several of our key customers require us to undergo a manufacturer certification process for new products in connection with the registration they undergo when registering a new product or formulation. This may involve an inspection by the customer’s own testing team of the product itself, focusing on quality testing, and of our manufacturing process by conducting plant audits. These manufacturer certifications are essential, because no sales to these customers can occur without such certifications. The testing is rigorous and can be time-consuming. We currently hold many certifications from key customers, but we cannot guarantee that we will not experience difficulties in retaining existing and obtaining new certifications as and when necessary. Failure to retain existing certifications or obtain new certifications may result in the loss of such customers. Any loss of, or significant reduction in demand from, one or more of our significant customers or termination of contracts with regards to any key product could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Changes in our customers’ products or processes can reduce the demand for our products.
Subsubsection Text: Our customers use our products for a broad range of applications. Changes in our customers’ products or processes may result in our customers reducing the volume of products they outsource to us or otherwise purchase from us, or even make our products unnecessary. Customers may also find alternative chemicals or processes that no longer require our products. For example, should a customer in Crop Science, Life Science or Performance Materials decide to use a different active ingredient or intermediate due to price, performance or other considerations, we may not be able to supply a product that meets the customer’s new requirements. In some instances, we are the key supplier to our customers with respect to selected key products. Consequently, the success of our products depends, to a significant extent, on the success of our customers’ own products in the relevant end-market. Conversely, new digitalization and technological advances could also lead to more efficient farming (through genetically modified seeds and more precise weather predictions) and our chemical products could ultimately be used more efficiently by our customers such that there is a decrease in demand. For example, genetically modified organisms could reduce or replace the need for insecticides or other Crop Science products. In addition, the improved availability and accuracy of field data could lead to more precision and efficiency in the use of herbicides, fungicides and insecticides for crop protection purposes and likewise lower the demand for our Crop Science products. Similarly, newly launched products might not reach the expected performance due to lack of sufficient demand in certain end-markets or customers decide to purchase lower volumes of our products. Any reduction in demand for herbicides, fungicides and insecticides products for which we supply advanced chemicals and active ingredients to our customers could negatively impact demand for our products. Additionally, our results of operations are influenced by the evolving nature of regulations impacting the industries in which our customers operate. We are also dependent on our customers’ continuous development of new products and their need for our production and technical expertise. If our customers were to fail to develop new products for which they outsource manufacturing to us, or if they otherwise do not require our production facilities or production facility capacity, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We rely on long-term contracts for a certain part of our revenue and growth prospects.
Subsubsection Text: For our CDMO business in Exclusives products, we produce specialized chemical products (mainly in Crop Science) in partnership with our clients to ensure we match their specific requirements and quality expectations. This requires significant ramp-up times and costs to set-up appropriate production lines and processes. We commit to such long-term projects (under contractual frameworks) with the expectation that we will recover our initial investments in the short-term and achieve desired returns and profitability growth in the mid- to long-term. The expected returns under these long-term contracts for Exclusives products account for a certain portion of our Group’s future growth and profitability prospects and if the actual returns do not match our expectations or if the contracts are breached, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Additionally, our CDMO contracts in Exclusives typically feature a minimum contractual length, as well as other mechanisms (e.g., co-investments by customers), targeting the recovery of our capital expenditure (“Capex”) for the project. We cover part of our initial Capex either through an initial investment from our clients or through contractual ‘take-or-pay’ clauses committing the clients to minimum purchase volumes and prices for an initial period. While this contribution from our clients to our costs helps integrate our services into their value chains and adds to their potential cost to switch suppliers, the custom production lines and processes developed this way are usually product specific and cannot be easily re-purposed in case a contract is terminated or otherwise 30 ----- modified. Should our customers refuse to renew existing contracts with such clauses, our profitability might be impacted. Furthermore, should a customer choose to exercise a force majeure clause, or otherwise refuse to tender payment for our services or terminate our contract, this would lead to losses or write-offs or additional costs on our part (such as increased storage and other costs). Conversely, we may be unsuccessful in exercising a force majeure clause ourselves, and as a result incur additional expenses under a contract that is no longer generating the expected returns. Furthermore, if such contracts are terminated for cause, or modified or breached by ourselves or our customers, we may not receive payment for our capital expenditures or generate the expected returns, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our results of operations may be affected by our inability to meet our customers’ requirements in terms of product quality, specifications or other terms.
Subsubsection Text: Our products may fail to meet our customers’ expectations in terms of quality, performance or otherwise, which may result in reputational harm, customers reducing the volume of orders they place with us or having to replace products at our expense. As many of our products are critical to, or enhance the performance of, our customers’ applications and products, our customers rely on us to provide them with products that meet their specifications and quality requirements. Our quality control systems and in-process production controls provide for regular inspection of our products. However, there can be no assurance that our products will meet agreed specifications or quality requirements, will not contain impurities or be mistakenly co-mingled with other products (for example, due to mislabeling) when initially produced. In the past, prior to distribution to the customer, our controls have identified completed products which have failed to meet customer specifications. In such instances, we have been required to re-run the manufacturing process to achieve the proper specifications, which has resulted in loss of revenue due to the need to deliver replacements at our own expense, reduction in sales volume due to the loss of diverted production capacity and delayed delivery of product to customers. Our contracts with our customers require our products to meet agreed specifications or quality requirements and therefore we may face similar consequences if we fail to detect such quality deficiencies in the first instance or otherwise deliver products which do not meet these requirements. In the event our quality systems identify issues only after shipping, we could further face the possibility of a recall, which could result in damage to our reputation, substantial additional work or destruction of material. Furthermore, some of our customers may ask us to manage the whole supply chain process (raw material sourcing, production and delivery) which would require increased resources and working capital, and therefore funding. If we are unable to obtain additional funding in order to finance increased working capital, we could fail to meet our customers’ demands. Any of these failures could also result in reputational harm and customers’ placing orders for lower volumes with us, which could also have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to risks related to conducting operations in several different countries.
Subsubsection Text: We currently have manufacturing facilities located in Germany, Switzerland, Finland, the United States and China. Our operations in these countries may be subject to the following risks: changes in the rate of economic growth; political or (macro-)economic conditions; availability and prices of raw materials and energy; supply chain disruptions; expropriation or other governmental actions; regulatory actions (including bans or restrictions on the usage of some of our products or their respective ingredients or substances); social unrest, war, terrorist activities or other armed conflict; bribery and corruption; national and regional labor strikes; confiscatory taxation or other adverse tax policies; deprivation of contract rights; trade restrictions and regulations affecting production, pricing and marketing of products; reduced protection of intellectual property rights; restrictions on the repatriation of income or capital; exchange controls and export restrictions; inflation; currency fluctuations and devaluation; the effect of global environmental, health and safety issues on economic conditions (including severe weather conditions), market opportunities and operating restrictions; and changes in financial policy and availability of credit. These factors could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to successfully implement our business strategies and capital expenditure plans.
Subsubsection Text: Our future financial performance and success depend on our ability to implement our business strategy successfully. We continue to focus on efficiency improvement initiatives to optimize our asset base, increase operating efficiencies and generate cost savings. We also continue to select suitable materials to build various process equipment, estimate raw material usage ratios, production capacity and waste generation as part of our business strategy. However, we cannot guarantee that we will be able to successfully implement our business strategies or that implementing these strategies will sustain or improve, rather than harm, our results of operations. 31 ----- In particular, we may not be able to maintain or increase our manufacturing efficiency or asset utilization or achieve other cost savings, such as the operational efficiency measures we are currently implementing in all of our international production facilities. In addition, the costs involved in implementing our strategies may be greater than we currently anticipate. For example, we have invested more than €25 million into a new production train in our Kokkola facility in Finland and we expanded into the United States in 2019 when the Permira Funds acquired Monitchem Kansas S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries, including Jayhawk Fine Chemicals Corporation and its production facility in Galena, Kansas, United States. However, our ability to continue similar capacity expansions in our production facilities may be delayed or interrupted by the need to obtain environmental and other regulatory approvals, the availability of labor and materials, unforeseen hazards, such as weather conditions and natural disasters, internal restructurings due to loss of customers or key products and other risks customarily associated with construction projects, including access to credit. See “We are dependent on a small number of Customers _and Key Products for a significant portion of our revenue.”_ Moreover, the capital expenditure that we estimate for use in such capacity expansion projects may be insufficient to cover the actual cost. We may experience cost overruns, and the cost of capacity expansion projects could have a negative impact on our financial results until capacity utilization is sufficiently high to absorb the incremental costs associated with the expansion. Our business strategy, in particular our production capacity expansion plans, is based on assumptions about future demand for our products and on our ability to optimize utilization of our existing and future production facilities. We cannot guarantee that we will be able to implement our strategy of optimizing utilization of assets in accordance with our plans or at all. For example, the frequency and length of facility maintenance and turnarounds (scheduled outages of a production facility in order to perform necessary inspections, tests to comply with industry regulations and any maintenance activities that may be necessary), planned restructurings and unplanned outages have had, and may in the future have, an impact on our operating results. Furthermore, major capacity expansions require long lead times in which operational business may be temporarily halted. Any failure to develop, revise or implement our strategy in a timely and effective manner may adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Seasonal fluctuations may impact our sales and cash flows.
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations for the first and fourth quarters of the year are generally stronger than our results of operation for the second and third quarters of the year, primarily due to seasonal factors in demand from our Crop Science customers. We typically experience the strongest demand in the fourth quarter of the year and the first quarter of the following year in line with increased demand for Crop Science products in the Northern Hemisphere each spring prior to the growing season. Further, seasonal fluctuations including adverse weather conditions (heat, cold, heavy rain, dryness, storm and exacerbated weather conditions due to climate change) may adversely affect certain of our markets and customers. Elevated temperatures may lead to prolonged vegetation periods and multiple harvests. Mild winters and strong humidity may lead to the increased spread of fungi, viruses and harmful insects and thus crop yields may decrease and/or the use of pesticides may increase. For example, in early 2019 severe North American weather conditions led to a temporary downturn due to limited crop planting in that region and in the summer of 2020, dry weather in Europe affected some of our customers, impacting demand. Furthermore, droughts and dry weather conditions in Europe, North, Central and South America in 2022 impacted the production of, amongst others, fruits, vegetables, soybeans and maize. In addition, most chemical production companies, including certain of our suppliers and customers, generally schedule repairs of machinery and production facility turnarounds (scheduled shutdowns of production units or facilities for maintenance) in the summer months, which may result in lower sales in the second and third quarters compared to the first and fourth quarters of a given year.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our competitive position and future prospects depend on our senior management’s experience and expertise and our ability to recruit and retain qualified personnel.
Subsubsection Text: The unanticipated departure of any key member of our senior management team could have an adverse effect on our business. In addition, because of the specialized and technical nature of our business, our future performance is dependent on the continued service of, and on our ability to attract and retain, qualified management, scientific, engineering, technical, marketing and support personnel. Competition for such personnel is intense, and we may be unable to continue to attract or retain such personnel. If we are unable to retain key personnel or attract new skilled personnel, it could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. 32 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We depend on good relations with our workforce, and any significant disruption could adversely affect us.
Subsubsection Text: For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, we employed an average of approximately 1,200 employees in our operations around the world. The countries in which we operate provide for various protections and rights for employees, as well as collective bargaining agreements. These protections and rights may require us to invest greater time and costs in amending employees’ terms of employment or make it more difficult to terminate employment contracts. For example, certain employees in Germany and Finland are represented by trade unions and works councils which generally must approve changes in conditions of employment, including salaries and benefits. The employees of Jayhawk are also members of a union. Litigation by labor representatives, a labor disturbance or work stoppage at any of our facilities as a result of any changes to our employment terms and conditions or for any other reason could have a material adverse effect on that facility’s operations and, potentially, on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our insurance coverage may not be adequate to protect us against all potential losses to which we may be subject, and it may be difficult to obtain replacement insurance on acceptable terms or at all.
Subsubsection Text: Due to the nature of the chemicals industry, our operations are generally difficult and expensive to insure. Our production facilities, equipment and other assets are insured for property damage and business interruption risks. However, our insurance does not cover mechanical equipment failure, and we may choose not to seek such coverage in the future due to our assessment of the cost effectiveness of entering into such policies and the possibility of mitigating such risks with spare parts or alternative sourcing options instead. We maintain liability, property, directors’ and officers’ and other insurance coverage with coverage limits we consider adequate for the size of our company and consistent with our business needs. However, we cannot be fully insured against all potential hazards incident to our business, including losses resulting from global conflicts or terrorist acts, certain natural catastrophes, environmental risks or other potential losses. Furthermore, there can be no assurance that any claim under our insurance policies will be honored fully or timely, our insurance coverage will be sufficient in any respect or our insurance premiums will not increase substantially. For example, after a fire incident at our Pratteln site in 2020, affected our production output, our insurance policy premium for property damage and business interruption more than doubled. We have experienced increases driven by inflation and other macroeconomic developments and insurance premiums may significantly increase in the future as a result of accidents of ours, other companies in Industrial Parks, or our competitors (which could be considered as industry risk) or due to changing market conditions. If we were to incur a significant liability for which we were not fully insured, or if premiums for certain insurance policies might increase substantially in the future as a result of any further incidents for which we are insured or as a result of general market forces, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Future acquisitions may prove difficult for us to complete and we may fail to realize the anticipated benefits from such acquisitions.
Subsubsection Text: We have a history of making and integrating acquisitions, such as our operations in Switzerland in 2007 (Pratteln), Finland in 2011 (Kokkola) and in the USA in 2019 (Jayhawk). In the future we may acquire companies or assets engaged businesses similar or complementary to ours. Restrictions in our existing financing agreements may preclude us from or limit our ability to make certain acquisitions. See “⸺Risks Related to Our Financial _Profile⸺We may not be able to generate sufficient cash to service our indebtedness and may be forced to take other actions to meet our obligations under our indebtedness, which may not be successful.”_ Further, we may use debt financing for any permitted acquisitions, which would increase our debt service requirements. If making acquisitions or integrating any acquired business diverts too much management attention from the existing operations, this could adversely affect our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows. Any acquisition that we make could be subject to a number of risks, including proposed acquisitions being prohibited or subject to onerous conditions by certain antitrust or other regulatory laws; problems with effective integration of operations; the inability to maintain key pre-acquisition business relationships; increased operating costs; costs related to achieving or maintaining compliance with laws, rules or regulations; costs related to postclosing asset impairment charges and expenses associated with eliminating duplicate facilities; the loss of key employees of the acquired company; exposure to unanticipated liabilities and unidentified loss contingencies; and difficulties in realizing projected efficiencies, synergies and cost savings. Integrating any future acquired business may result in additional unforeseen difficulties or liabilities and could impact the effectiveness of our internal controls over financial reporting. 33 ----- We cannot guarantee that any of our future acquisitions will ultimately provide the benefits we originally anticipate, including the expected business growth opportunities, revenue benefits, cost synergies and other operational efficiencies. Furthermore, we may not succeed in identifying attractive acquisition candidates or financing and completing potential acquisitions on favorable terms. Any of the foregoing or other factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may fail to realize anticipated benefits from joint ventures.
Subsubsection Text: We have made, and may continue to make, investments and enter into joint ventures. For example, in 2014 we established a joint venture with Shandong Lutai Chemical Co., Ltd. (formerly Jining Jinwei Gold Power Co., Ltd.), a state-owned enterprise, to serve the market in Northern China and serve as a platform for further growth in China. We have a 68 % interest in the joint venture with Shandong Lutai Chemical which contributes to less than 1% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The success of joint ventures or arrangements with third parties is not always predictable, and we may not realize our anticipated objectives or benefits. Such arrangements may require significant initial expenditures as well as ongoing expenditures for modernization and expansion. Furthermore, the ability to receive dividends, royalties and other payments from joint ventures depends not only on the joint venture’s cash flows and profits, but also upon the terms of the joint venture agreement with our partner. Conflicts with joint venture partners may lead to deadlock and may result in our inability to pursue our desired strategy or exit from the joint venture on favorable terms. From time to time, we may require the approval of a joint venture partner and any delay or difficulties in obtaining such approval could have a negative impact on our business. In addition, sales or transfers of our interests in joint ventures may be subject to the written approval of the joint venture partner, rights of first offer and, in the case of our joint venture with Shandong Lutai Chemical, to the approval of certain Chinese regulatory authorities. Furthermore, the bankruptcy, insolvency or severe financial distress of a joint venture partner or the joint venture itself or any new regulations, international trade restrictions or enforcements to which they become subject could adversely affect the joint venture and lead to its liquidation or a sale of our joint venture interest at a loss and, as a result, could affect our reputation as well as our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may be subject to information technology systems failures, cyberattacks, network disruptions and breaches of data security.
Subsubsection Text: Our information technology systems are an important element of effectively operating our business. Information technology systems failures, including risks associated with upgrading our systems, network disruptions and breaches of data security could disrupt our operations by impeding our processing of transactions, our ability to protect customer or company information and our financial reporting, leading to increased costs. It is possible that future technological developments could adversely affect the functionality of our computer systems and require further action, which could require us to spend substantial funds to prevent or repair computer malfunctions. Our computer systems, including our back-up systems, could be damaged or interrupted by power outages, computer and telecommunications failures, computer viruses, internal or external security breaches, including cyberattacks, events such as fires, earthquakes, or floods and/or errors by our employees. Security vulnerabilities in information technology solutions and insufficient contingency planning measures may lead to incidents that affect the entire Group. As such threats, particularly around cybersecurity, continue to evolve we may be required to expend significant resources to enhance our control environment, processes, practices and other protective measures. Although we have taken steps to address these concerns by implementing network security, back-up systems, cybersecurity insurance and internal control measures, there can be no assurance that a system failure or data security breach and/or the resulting loss of trade secrets or other intellectual property will not have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Furthermore, based on the EU Data and Digital Strategies, there are several initiatives pending and new laws passed aimed at establishing a single, uniform digital European market with robust cybersecurity requirements, including the Digital Services Act, the Data Act, the Directive EU 2022/2557 on the resilience of critical entities (so-called NIS2 Directive), the Cyber Resilience Act and the Artificial Intelligence Act. Overall, implementing and complying with these laws may lead to us incurring higher costs or having to change our business practices in this respect. In addition, confidential information that we maintain may be subject to misappropriation, theft and deliberate or unintentional misuse by current or former employees, third-party contractors or other parties. Any such misappropriation and/or misuse of our information could result in us, among other things, being in breach of certain global data privacy, data protection, localization, security and consumer-protection laws and regulations. In general, data privacy laws regulate when and how personal data of employees, customers or any other third-party may be collected, for which purposes they may be processed and/or used, for how long they may be stored and to whom and how they may be transferred. These laws and regulations are emerging and evolving 34 ----- in countries worldwide and the interpretation and application of these laws and regulations in the European Union, the United States and elsewhere are often uncertain, contradictory and changing. For example, we are subject to the European General Data Protection Regulation (EU 2016/679) (“GDPR”), under which we have compliance obligations regarding the treatment (so-called processing) of personal data, including notification obligations of personal data breaches and additional requirements for sharing personal data with any recipient outside the European Economic Area. Furthermore, the GDPR inter alia requires the implementation of appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure the data security in general. Under the GDPR, breaches of data protection rules may result in maximum fines equal to the greater of €20 million and 4% of the annual global turnover of the group of the sanctioned company. It is possible that the GDPR and other laws may be interpreted or applied in a manner that is adverse to us, unforeseen, or otherwise inconsistent with our practices or that we may not adequately adapt our internal policies and/or procedures to evolving regulations, any of which could result in litigation, regulatory investigations and potential legal liability, require us to change our practices in a manner adverse to our business or limit access to our products and services in certain countries. As a result, our reputation and brand may be harmed, we could incur substantial costs, and we could lose both customers and revenue. Our failure to comply with applicable data protection laws and regulations could result in enforcement actions against us, including fines, imprisonment of company officials and public censure, claims for damages by affected individuals, the imposition of integrity obligations and agency oversight and damage to our reputation, any of which could harm our business. Evolving and changing definitions of personal data and personal information, within the European Union, the United States and elsewhere, may limit or inhibit our ability to operate or expand our business, including limiting strategic partnerships that may involve sharing of personal data. Moreover, if the relevant laws and regulations change, or are interpreted and applied in a manner that is inconsistent with our data practices or if we expand into new markets and are required to comply with new requirements, we may need to expend resources in order to change our business operations or data practices. Even the perception of privacy concerns, whether or not valid, may harm our reputation. The occurrence of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may be required to increase our pension fund contributions.
Subsubsection Text: We have pension commitments to our existing and some of our former employees. These commitments are partially covered by a pension scheme, pension funds, special purpose funds and insurance policies. As of December 31, 2022, we have provisions for pensions and similar obligations in the amount of €18.1 million. The amount of obligations is based on certain actuarial assumptions, including discount factors, life expectancy, pension trends and future salary development as well as expected interest rates applicable to the applicable plan, scheme or fund assets. If the actual results deviate from these assumptions, it could result in a considerable increase of the pension commitments and thus to higher allocations to pension reserves in future years and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our tax burden could increase as a result of future tax audits and potential changes in applicable tax laws and regulations.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to routine tax audits by local tax authorities in the countries in which we operate. Future tax audits may result in additional tax and interest payments, which would negatively affect our financial condition and results of operation. Changes in fiscal regulations or the interpretation of tax laws by the courts or the tax authorities in the foreign jurisdictions in which we conduct our business may also have negative consequences. In addition, tax authorities may, to some extent, not accept the deductibility of interest payments, claiming among other aspects, that limitation under interest ceiling rules or transfer pricing rules apply. In such event, we may face additional tax payments becoming due in tax audits or in the process of tax assessments. Any additional tax payments could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to currency fluctuation risks in several different countries that could adversely affect our profitability.
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations may be affected by transaction effects and translation effects of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations. We are exposed to transaction effects when one of our subsidiaries incurs costs or generates sales in a currency different from its functional currency. Fluctuations in exchange rates may also affect the relative competitive position of our production facilities, as well as our ability to market our products successfully in other markets. We are exposed to currency fluctuations when we convert currencies we receive for our products into currencies required to pay our debt or currencies used to purchase raw materials, meet our fixed costs or pay for services, which could result in a gain or loss depending on fluctuations in exchange rates. 35 ----- Certain of our sales are invoiced in currencies other than the euro, namely Swiss francs, Chinese yuan and U.S. dollars, while our consolidated sales are reported in euro. If the value of the euro declines against currencies in which our obligations are denominated or increases against currencies in which our sales are denominated, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be adversely affected.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to the risk of loss resulting from non-payment or non-performance by our customers.
Subsubsection Text: Our customers may experience financial difficulties, including bankruptcies, restructurings and liquidations. These and other financial problems that may be experienced by our customers, as well as potential financial weaknesses in our industry, may increase our risk in extending trade credit to customers. We have limited credit risk insurance, which does not extend to protect us against all potential losses to which we may be subject. A significant adverse change in a customer relationship or in a customer’s financial position could cause us to limit or discontinue business with that customer, require us to assume more credit risk relating to that customer’s receivables or limit our ability to collect accounts receivable from that customer, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows. Furthermore, should a customer choose to exercise a force majeure clause in their contract and refuse to tender payment for our services, this would lead to increased storage and costs on our part or even losses or write-offs. Conversely, we may exercise a force majeure clause in a business contract and the customer may successfully challenge this exercise. All of these circumstances could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Environmental, social and governance matters may impact our business and reputation.
Subsubsection Text: There has been increased focus by regulators, consumers, investors, employees, and other stakeholders, as well as by governmental and non-governmental organizations, on environmental, social and governance matters (“ESG”). This has resulted in expanding and increasingly complex mandatory and voluntary reporting, diligence, and disclosure on ESG topics. These developments and other rapidly changing laws, regulations, policies and related interpretations, as well as increased enforcement actions or investigations by various governmental and regulatory agencies and increased litigation risk from private parties, may alter the environment in which we do business and may increase the ongoing costs of compliance which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Any failure or perceived failure to meet our ESG commitments or targets, or loss of confidence, or inability to meet expectations with our ESG commitments on the part of customers, investors, employees and other stakeholders as it relates to our ESG initiatives could negatively impact our business relationships, and the demand for our products. These impacts could be difficult and costly to overcome, even if such concerns were based on inaccurate or misleading information. In addition, achieving our ESG initiatives may result in increased costs in our supply chain, fulfillment, and/or business operations. Standards regarding ESG initiatives could change and become more onerous for us to meet successfully. Evolving data and research could undermine or refute our current claims and beliefs that we have made in reliance on current research, which could also result in additional costs or a decrease in revenue, negative market perception and increased scrutiny that could have a material adverse effect on our business and financial condition. A variety of organizations measure the performance of companies on such ESG topics, and the results of these assessments are widely publicized. In addition, investment in funds that specialize in companies that perform well in such assessments is increasingly popular, and major institutional investors have publicly emphasized the importance of such ESG measures to their investment decisions. Topics taken into account in such assessments include, among others, a company’s efforts and impacts on climate change and human rights, ethics and compliance with law and the role of a company’s board of directors in supervising various sustainability issues. In light of investors’ increased focus on ESG matters, there can be no certainty that we will manage such issues successfully, or that we will successfully meet society’s ESG expectations or achieve our financial goals. As part of our commitment to ESG matters, we have introduced specific, quantifiable key performance indicators. If we fail to meet the targets of these or other key performance indicators to measure our progress towards our ESG goals, we may suffer reputational damage, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. 36 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our operations are subject to hazards such as chemical spills, unforeseen shutdowns and natural catastrophes which could result in significant disruptions and liability for us. We have experienced chemical spills in the past and may continue to experience such events.
Subsubsection Text: The hazards and risks of disruption associated with chemical manufacturing and the related storage and transportation of raw materials, products and wastes exist in our operations and the operations of other occupants with whom we share manufacturing sites, including our suppliers. These potential risks of disruption include, but are not necessarily limited to: - unplanned production or power disruptions; - failure of mechanical, process safety and pollution control equipment; - pipeline and storage tank leaks and ruptures; - explosions and fires; - inclement weather and natural disasters (including earthquakes, the development of sinkholes and tornados); - construction of national highways affecting our facilities; - cyber-attacks and other external assaults on our IT-systems or digital infrastructure; - terrorist attacks; - political turmoil; - chemical spills and other discharges or releases of toxic or hazardous substances or gases; - exposure to toxic chemicals; and/or - other accidents. These interruptions and hazards could also lead to a short- or long-term suspension of operations, expose employees, customers, the community and others to toxic chemicals and other hazards, contaminate the environment, damage property, result in personal injury or death, damage our reputation and adversely affect the productivity and profitability of a particular manufacturing facility or our business operations as a whole, and result in the need for remediation, governmental enforcement, regulatory shutdowns, the imposition of government fines and penalties and claims brought by governmental entities or third parties. In addition, the occurrence of any such event could harm our ability to obtain or maintain our existing licenses or our key commercial, regulatory, and governmental relationships. For example, in the past we have experienced chemical spills and leakages in certain of our sites, including Kokkola and Pratteln. Furthermore, a part of our Pratteln site sits in an area with increased risk of landslides and sinkholes, with one such sinkhole collapse event occurring in 2018. While we have made foundation improvements to our plants as part of investments to protect against earthquakes and believe the risk to our operations is limited, unexpected natural disasters, including landslides and sinkholes, may cause significant damage or delays in our plants. Legal claims and regulatory actions could subject us to civil liability, administrative sanctions and criminal penalties, which could affect our product sales, reputation and profitability. In many jurisdictions, such as the United States, these risks are amplified by the frequency of class action lawsuits and high punitive damages awards. Furthermore, our existing environmental, health and safety compliance and management systems set-up to prevent potential risks, enable emergency responses and crisis management plans and mitigate damages may not successfully prevent or mitigate these risks. Should any of these risks materialize, our production capacity could be materially adversely affected, which could in turn negatively impact our sales and potentially lead to a loss of market share. This could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. 37 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We have experienced in the past and may continue to face unplanned production disruptions, manufacturing interruptions and delays at our facilities worldwide.
Subsubsection Text: We currently have six manufacturing sites, four located in Europe, one in China and one in the United States. In the ordinary course of business, we may face unplanned production disruptions due to unforeseen events such as fires, power shortages, sabotage, accidents or natural catastrophes, resulting in significant operational disruptions, delays, costs, or liability. For example, in 2020, a fire incident at our Pratteln site led to a partial standstill of the chlorine value chain, which negatively impacted production and therefore sales of our products, negatively affecting our revenue in 2020. In addition, in February 2021, our Jayhawk facility experienced a seven-day standstill due to a severe winter storm. As a result, we incurred substantial costs and expenses due to this standstill. Some of the crucial equipment, infrastructure systems and storage systems used within our various plants (for example: incineration boilers, mixer settlers, reactors or utility infrastructure systems) may also experience damages, decreased quality in terms of functionality or restraints due to either unforeseen events or normal wear and tear. Although we possess customary insurance for damage to our property and the disruption of our business, and, for example, we were able to claim back certain losses from the fire incident at our Pratteln site, such plans and insurance may not cover all such disasters or be sufficient to cover all of our potential losses and may not continue to be available to us on acceptable terms or at all. In addition, such disruptions could impact our relationships with our clients, all of which could have a negative impact on our business. Additionally, adverse weather or other natural catastrophes such as flooding, severe storms, landslides, earthquakes or others, whether caused by climate change or natural processes of the earth, may significantly affect our production sites and cause severe disruptions and some of our production facilities worldwide may be more exposed to such risks. For example, a past geological survey conducted at our Pratteln site in Switzerland, revealed that the site is subject to seismic activity and earthquake risk. We have already explored and initiated a seismic retrofitting process which, however, is envisaged to take several years for completion. If disruptions occur, alternative facilities with sufficient capacity or capabilities may not be available, may cost substantially more or it may take significant time to start production. Each of these scenarios could materially adversely affect our business and financial performance. If any of our production facilities is unable to manufacture our products for an extended period of time, our sales may decline due to the disruption and we may not be able to manufacture sufficient volumes of products to meet our customers’ needs. Furthermore, our production processes and supply chains are highly integrated and any disruptions to such production processes or supply chains may negatively impact the sales of our products. For example, the fire accident at our Pratteln site in 2020 affected not only our products used in the Crop Science and Life Science industries but also, as a result of our integrated production network, our products which are used in the Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals industry. As the production of one of the key chemicals manufactured at the Pratteln site depends on monochloroacetic acid (MCA) sourced from our Knapsack and Gersthofen facilities, we lost volumes of MCA during the outage due to the reduced demand at Pratteln while production capacity was down. Furthermore, we may face work-related accidents and near-misses on part of the employees and workers in our plants. Although we believe we maintain disaster recovery plans in line with customary industry standards and possess customary insurance for damage to our property and the disruption of our business from casualties, such plans and insurance may not cover all such disasters or be sufficient to cover all of our potential losses and may not continue to be available to us on acceptable terms or at all. Any inability to recover from a third-party any or all compensation related to a disruption could have a negative impact on our business. In addition, any inability to meet our customers’ needs could cause them to seek other suppliers. Furthermore, to the extent a disruption occurs at a production facility that has been operating at or near full capacity, the resulting shortage of our product could be particularly harmful because production at the facility may not be able to reach levels achieved prior to the disruption. Shutdowns, strikes, weather or other disruptions affecting our upstream supply chain or our utilities or logistics providers, could have a negative impact on our business. Any such disruptions and the resulting repercussions may adversely impact our reputation, business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We rely on third parties for the performance of transportation and logistical services.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on third-party service providers for certain aspects of our business, particularly the receipt of raw materials from our suppliers and the transport and distribution of our products to our customers as well as certain services related to waste disposal. Our ability to receive vital raw materials, to provide our products to our customers and to dispose of our waste depends on our ability to negotiate reasonable terms with third parties, 38 ----- including railroad, trucking and shipping companies. To the extent that our third-party service providers increase their rates, including to reflect higher fuel, maintenance, labor or other costs due to increased regulation, taxation or otherwise, we may not be able to pass on such increases to our customers in a timely manner or at all. In certain instances, we depend on a single or limited number of third-party service providers, including for our chlorine supply in Knapsack or certain waste disposal services across the Group. Any disruption to our third-party service providers may lead to standstills or otherwise negatively impact our ability to manufacture our products (due to a lack of, for example, raw materials and energy supply (e.g. steam)), to deliver our products to our customers or to continue our operations in the event we cannot find any alternative provider, in particular if the availability of a particular type of service provider is limited or if we depend on only one provider. Any material increases in our transport and distribution costs that we are unable to pass on to customers or any disruption to our transportation and logistical network, including waste disposal, could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation or cash flows. For example, transportation routes between cities in Germany and Switzerland have limited capacity and if there is no alternative container or tank wagon that can transport products to and from our sites, our customers would fail to receive their ordered products or our own production sites would fail to receive the raw materials. Inability to deliver ordered products to customers may also lead to additional unpredicted costs for storage. Some of the chemicals we transport also face transportation and loading restrictions – for example, certain of our materials are not approved by authorities for transportation by vehicular means, which further limits the number of alternative transportation means available.
