Furthermore, our suppliers in China have faced the risk of unexpected delivery delays as a result of China’s zero-COVID policy and may face in the future the risk of similar political measures in which the detection of a single case of COVID19 may lead to the shut-down of an entire port. See “⸺Risks Related to the Industry in which We Operate⸺The _spread of the 2019 coronavirus (“COVID-19”) has had, and the outbreak of another infectious disease or other serious public health concern around the world could have, a negative impact on economies, financial markets and business activities.”_ Future disruptions of this nature may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation or cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may face capacity constraints that could compromise our ability to meet customer expectations or overcapacity that could negatively impact our results.
Subsubsection Text: If we encounter capacity limitations or fail to effectively manage our capacity, our business could suffer either as a result of not meeting customer expectations (e.g., inability to meet agreed delivery deadlines) or having to decline potential new business opportunities. Conversely, if we are not able to effectively manage our capacity or there is a decline in customer demand, and, as a result, we experience underutilization of certain sites, this could lead to overcapacity and result in profit margin erosion due to the high fixed costs of our manufacturing sites. Currently, certain of our facilities are operating at high capacity. Any disruptions in the manufacturing of chemicals at these sites, including due to capacity constraints, could impact our ability to fulfill the respective customer manufacturing contracts. In addition, the volume of manufacturing for different chemicals varies across our sites, with some sites having certain focuses and specialties. Thus, if there is increased demand in a certain manufactured chemical, we may experience over-capacity at select manufacturing sites, while other sites operate at less efficient levels. In some cases, we may not be able to easily or quickly shift production between sites employing the same methodology or technology due to the specific manufacturing requirements of our customers’ customized products (including regulatory requirements). As a result, we may face significant challenges in managing our capacity. If we are unable to manage effectively or optimally our capacity in light of changing customer requirements, which can vary and shift across the quarters of the financial year, we may experience operational inefficiencies and site underutilization or need to reduce the volumes of more profitable products to manufacture contractually committed volumes of other products. Furthermore, such risks may be greater at facilities that are new or going through significant expansion or renovation. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. 39 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on the availability of raw materials and any shortages, lack of delivery or price increases may lead to manufacturing interruptions and/or increases in manufacturing costs, and may also limit our ability to grow our business.
Subsubsection Text: We produce a certain amount of raw materials ourselves, however, we also procure raw materials from third parties. As such, our manufacturing processes are dependent on the availability of various raw materials, including, inter alia, acetic acid, other carboxylic acids, acetic acid anhydride, lactic acid derivatives, chlorine in sites where we do not produce it ourselves, and various solvents and catalysts. While we rely on a number of third-party suppliers to provide us with raw materials and supplies, it is possible that any of our third-party suppliers could be interrupted due to changing regulatory requirements, import or export restrictions, natural disasters, international supply disruptions, geopolitical issues, strikes, shortages, financial, operational or quality issues at a supplier’s facilities and other events or could be terminated in the future. Our third-party suppliers may close production sites causing supply chain problems and any decision by our suppliers to fail to deliver certain materials in part or at all may negatively impact our business. In addition, our third-party suppliers may deliver defective raw materials that fall out of the agreed specifications in which case such raw materials would be returned. For example, macroeconomic developments or other events such as the RussiaUkraine conflict may negatively impact raw material supply chains, affecting the availability of raw materials needed for our production or used by our customers. As a result of any of these factors, we may be unable to source input products from other suppliers upon short notice and/or at the required volume. Any such delay or failure of delivery by our suppliers could result in delaying our customers’ production schedule, which could result in loss of business and reputational damage. See “⸺Risks Related to the Industry in Which We _Operate⸺Economic downturns or worsening global economic conditions may adversely impact our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows” and “⸺The Russia-Ukraine conflict and the resulting sanctions and measures taken against Russia have had and may have further adverse material effects on the global economy, energy supplies and prices, and may have severe adverse effects on the operations of energy- intensive sectors (e.g., heavy industry, chemical manufacturers, metallurgy, pharma, etc.).”_ In certain instances, for example where the supply of raw materials to our production site requires a specific infrastructure such as a pipeline, we may also depend on a single supplier. For example, our plants in Knapsack and Jining depend on adjacent suppliers to supply chlorine via a pipeline. Furthermore, at our Gersthofen and Pratteln sites, we rely on a single third-party supplier for salt. Any lack of availability suppliers could have detrimental effects on our production capacity at such sites. See “⸺We rely on third parties for the performance _of transportation and logistical services” and “⸺Risks Related to the Industry in Which We Operate⸺The spread of the 2019 coronavirus (“COVID-19”) has had, and the outbreak of another infectious disease or other serious public health concern around the world could have, a negative impact on economies, financial markets and business activities.”_ We have historically been able to partially pass on increases in raw materials costs to our customers when the prices for the purchase of raw materials increased, for example, through raw material price adjustment clauses in some of our agreements and corresponding price annexes. In certain instances, we also partially pass on transportation, energy and packaging costs to our customers. However, there is a risk that we will not always be able to do so in the future and any significant and/or unexpected increases in the cost of raw materials or transportation costs that we are unable to pass on to our customers (at least in part) or that lead to a significant increase of costs in business relationships based on contracts that do not contain adjustment mechanisms could have a negative impact on our financial results. Furthermore, even if we continue to pass on a portion of the cost of raw materials and transportation costs to our customers, the cost of such raw materials and/or transportation costs may increase to a significantly higher price such that customers would seek other suppliers. In addition, several of our raw materials suppliers are based in China and any changes to the environmental, health and safety laws and regulations in this region will likely impact certain chemical sites, including those of our third-party suppliers. Such changes could result in increased costs of such raw materials, delay in the production of such raw materials and, in turn, could impact our supply chain and our ability to meet our own chemical product delivery timelines. See “⸺Risks Related to Our Business⸺We are exposed to risks related to conducting _operations in several different countries.” On the other hand, we may also experience challenges in managing our_ inventory due to, inter alia, customer order cancellations or inaccurate manufacturing forecasts. Any inability to manage our inventory levels could result in such inventory becoming obsolete, resulting in write-downs of certain purchased raw materials and supplies. Any change in inventories, whether an increase or decrease, affects our cash flow and other financial results. 40 ----- These challenges may become even more significant as we endeavor to expand our business, requiring additional and new raw materials. Decisions to expand capacity may be delayed due to sourcing and supply chain problems. In addition to these risks, governmental regulations, environmental laws and regulations, increasing demand for raw materials from competitors and the effects of third-party supplier consolidation may also lead to temporary or permanent shortages of raw materials. Any sustained interruption in our receipt of adequate raw materials and/or supplies or significant price increase of such materials and/or supplies could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Increased energy costs, disruptions in energy supplies or our inability to pass on energy costs could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is dependent on the steady supply of significant amounts of energy, in particular electricity for our electrolysis production processes in Pratteln and Knapsack. For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, our energy costs recognized in cost of sales amounted to €65.6 million, or 8.7% of our revenue. Energy costs are affected by various factors, including the availability of supplies of particular sources of energy, energy prices and regulatory decisions. In particular, prices for oil, gas and electricity have been volatile in recent years, and such volatility may continue as a result of geopolitical instability, such as the Russia-Ukraine conflict. In addition, electricity prices for industrial consumers in Germany and Switzerland are generally higher than in several neighboring countries. Any significant increase in market prices, transportation costs, grid fees or taxes (including by reduction of tax benefits) associated with the supply of energy would increase our operating costs and, thus, may negatively affect our results of operations if we are not able to pass a certain portion of the increased costs on to our customers. Any deficiencies in our contracts with our customers or our suppliers, such as a misstatement or misapplication of a price formula, any disagreement with respect to the interpretation of a price formula or other unforeseen events, such as increasing energy prices, could result in an increase in our energy costs and could result in an inability to pass on increases in energy costs to our customers. In addition, any significant disruption in our energy supply at any of our facilities as a result of outages, stoppages, supply chain issues, regulators or public authorities requesting reduction in energy consumption as a result of supply issues or other reasons, could impact our supply chain and our ability to fulfill our customer manufacturing contracts. Any inability or delay in passing on increases in energy costs to our customers or any interruption or shortage of energy supply from our suppliers may negatively impact our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Environmental and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: Compliance with increasing regulatory requirements concerning the testing, labelling, registration and safety analysis of our products may result in significant additional costs for us or may reduce or eliminate the availability and/or marketability of some of the raw materials we use or of our products. Our inability to maintain our existing classification registration in member states of the European Union under the REACH legislation, or comparable legislation in other countries in which we operate or do business, may affect our ability to manufacture and sell certain products.
Subsubsection Text: To operate a chemical manufacturing business and to sell and distribute chemical products involves safety health and environmental risks. As part of our business, we store, handle, transport and use certain substances or components that may be considered toxic or hazardous. If operational risks - such as fires, leaks, releases and explosions - materialize, they could result in injury or loss of life, damage to the environment or loss of production. We must comply with a broad range of regulations related to the testing, manufacturing, registration, labeling and safety analysis of our products or the products of our suppliers. In some countries, including the Member States of the European Union (particularly Finland and Germany), Switzerland, the United States and China, these types of regulatory controls and restrictions have become increasingly demanding and we expect this trend to continue. For example, our products and raw materials produced or imported into the European Union are subject to extensive environmental and industrial hygiene regulations governing the registration and safety analysis of the substances contained in them. The European Union Regulation on the Registration, Evaluation and Authorization 41 ----- of Chemicals (Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006), (“REACH”), imposes significant obligations on the chemicals industry as a whole with respect to the testing, evaluation, assessment and registration of basic chemicals and more advanced chemicals. The review and update of existing registrations is expensive and time-consuming and lead to increased production costs and reduced operating margins for chemical products. We also cannot exclude with certainty that the European Chemicals Agency (“ECHA”) may not designate some of our other products as substances of very high concern (“SVHCs”) and thereby require authorization and a strict safety evaluation for them under REACH. ECHA is also responsible to evaluate potential restrictions of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (“PFASs”) that have been proposed by the Member States. PFASs are a large class of thousands of synthetic chemicals that are used throughout society. They are increasingly detected as environmental pollutants and some are linked to negative effects on human health. PFASs have been frequently observed to contaminate groundwater, surface water and soil. A number of PFASs are already on the REACH candidate list of SVHCs, for example perfluorinated carboxylic acids (C9-14 PFCAs) and PFHxS. On January 13, 2023, a proposal prepared by the competent national authorities of, inter alia, Denmark, Germany and Sweden to restrict around 10,000 PFASs was submitted to ECHA. All PFASs in the scope of the proposal are very persistent in the environment and the national authorities estimate that around 4.4 million tonnes of PFASs would end up in the environment over the next 30 years unless action is taken. ECHA’s scientific committees are currently evaluating the proposal. The evaluation will also take into consideration the results and the input from a six-month public consultation that started on March 22, 2023. Afterwards, ECHA’s scientific committees will adopt formal opinions, based on which the European Commission and the Member States will then decide on the potential restrictions. We cannot exclude that the proposed restrictions of the use of PFASs may have a negative impact on our business activities. Moreover, under the Biocidal Products Regulation (EU) No. 528/2012 we have to apply for approval of active substances at ECHA and for product authorization before placing a biocidal product on the market. In connection with REACH or the EU Classification, Labeling and Packaging Regulation (Regulation (EC) No. 1272/2008) (“CLP”), some key raw materials, chemicals or substances, including our products, could be reclassified as having a toxicological or health-related impact on the environment, on users of our products, or on our employees. Furthermore, the European Directive No. 2010/75/EC on industrial emissions (“IED Directive”) sets out rules on the prevention and control of pollution from industrial activities and includes rules aimed at reducing emissions into air, water and land, as well as preventing the generation of waste in order to achieve a high level of overall environmental protection. Although the IED Directive and its implementation provide transitional provisions, once a new industry standard becomes binding, existing permits, which are not in compliance with such standard can become invalid. We have in the past incurred, and will in the future incur, significant cost for capital and operating expenditures to obtain and maintain necessary permits. In the European Union, the “European Green Deal”, a strategy aiming at making Europe the first climate-neutral continent by 2050, will have a considerable impact on the industry throughout all sectors, including on our business. The implementation of the “European Green Deal” involves revisions of a large number of regulations, including REACH, CLP and the IED Directive. The “European Green Deal” is still in the process of being implemented, with many bills in the legislative process, and the impact on our business cannot yet be predicted in detail. However, we will be facing a stricter regulatory framework in many respects going forward. In addition, the Toxic Substances Control Act (“TSCA”) mandates that the United States Environmental Protection Agency (“EPA”) conduct safety evaluations for all chemicals in active commerce and determine that new chemicals and significant new uses of chemicals are not likely to present an unreasonable risk before entering the market. With respect to any facilities we operate or may operate in the United States and with respect to any products we sell or may in the future sell in the United States, classification or reclassification of one or more of our raw materials or products could affect our ability to manufacture or market our products, result in a ban on purchase or sale of our products or raw materials or require us to incur increased costs to comply with notification, labelling, handling, or other requirements. Furthermore, all pesticide products sold in the United States must comply with the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act (“FIFRA”), and most must be registered with the U.S. EPA and similar state agencies. Our inability to obtain or maintain such registrations, or the cancellation of any such registration of our products, could have an adverse effect on our business, the severity of which would depend on a variety of factors, including the product(s) involved, whether another product could be substituted and whether our competitors were similarly affected. We attempt to anticipate regulatory developments and maintain registrations of, and access to, substitute active ingredients, but there can be no assurance that we will be able to avoid or reduce these risks. 42 ----- In Germany, applicable environmental laws include, for example, air emissions laws (Immissionsschutzrecht), soil protection laws (Bodenschutzrecht), water protection laws (Gewässerschutzrecht), waste laws (Abfallrecht) and plant safety laws (Anlagensicherheitsrecht). In the past, we have incurred costs and expenses due to exceeding volatile organic compound (VOC) emission thresholds. We also continue to incur costs and expenses in relation to waste water disposal and certain rehabilitation measures required under applicable laws. However, such future costs and expenses are difficult to predict. These and other regulatory requirements affecting our products that have been adopted or may be adopted in the future could negatively affect the availability, marketability, transportation flexibility or disposability (including quantity of disposability) of the raw materials or products we use, result in a restriction or ban on their purchase or sale, or require us to incur increased costs to comply with notification labelling, handling or storage capacity requirements. Because some of these regulations have only recently been enacted or proposed, we are not in a position to predict with certainty their expected cost impact with specificity. In addition, as some of our products are sold into markets in which the correct classification is at the discretion of the legal regime applicable to those substances, we cannot exclude that competent authorities or third parties could question or contest our classification. Any of these factors could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Environmental and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We may face additional liabilities and may incur significant costs related to contamination from hazardous substances or residual pollution.
Subsubsection Text: We have to comply with stringent procedures governing handling, storing and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes, and comply with rules on soil and groundwater contamination, and employee health and safety of which historically we have experienced violations and citations. We are also subject to laws and regulations governing the destruction and disposal of raw materials and non-compliant products, the handling of regulated materials included in our products, and the disposal of our products or their components (including capacity limits of disposed waste) at the end of their useful lives. We also cannot assure that we will dispose of our internal waste in a cost-effective manner. This can require significant expenditures and non-compliance may result in the limitation or suspension of manufacturing or subject us to stricter regulation, prohibition to use such substances, material monetary fines and penalties, civil or criminal sanctions, or other liabilities. In the past we have experienced several environmental incidents at our various manufacturing sites that have required certain clean-up efforts. In each case, the local sites were in contact with the respective authorities, and the matters have been closed without further action or remediation required although continuous monitoring is required in certain cases. There can be no assurance that we will be able to resolve any further issues of a similar or differing nature in the same manner or that future incidents will not require significant remediation. Contamination or residual pollution at any formerly owned or operated properties can also result in liability. In the event of the discovery of new or previously unknown contamination either at our facilities or at third-party locations, including facilities we formerly owned or operated, the issuance of additional requirements with respect to existing contamination or residual pollution, or the imposition of other clean-up obligations for which we are responsible, we may be required to take additional, unplanned remedial measures for which we have not recorded reserves. Furthermore, environmental laws may expose us to liability for the conduct of or conditions caused by others, and some environmental laws provide for joint and several strict liability for releases of hazardous substances into the environment, which could result in liability for environmental damage without regard to negligence or fault. Furthermore, regulators might ban or restrict the usage of some of our products or their respective ingredients or substances in the future. See “⸺Risks Related to the Industry in Which We Operate⸺We are subject to stringent _environmental, health and safety laws and regulations across multiple jurisdictions. We are highly regulated and may incur significant costs to maintain compliance with, or address liabilities under, environmental, health and safety laws and regulations applicable to our business.”_ Should any of the above factors occur, this may result in an increase in our costs and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. 43 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Environmental and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: We have experienced chemical spillages in the past which may be harmful to human health and operate on sites which contain legacy pollution and contamination. We may be liable for damages, site remediation or other environmental and health-related matters.
Subsubsection Text: Some of our production sites have a long history of industrial chemical processing, storage and related activities, including the processing of harmful materials and we have experienced chemical spillages and leakages in the past. Many of our production sites sit on top of contaminated soil. For example, plots of land on the Pratteln site are partially located on contaminated sites which are registered in the Swiss cantonal cadastre of polluted sites. Due to industrial use in the past, such plots of land partially contain contaminated soil, for example, low amounts (in most cases) of metolachlor, lead, cadmium, zinc, nickel and mercury. According to section 36 of Umweltschutzgesetz Basel-Landschaft (USG BL), we must examine, treat and dispose of contaminated soil in a proper way before commencing construction. We currently remain compliant with this regulation. The Jayhawk site in Kansas is subject to a Consent Agreement entered into in June 1999 between several respondents and the Kansas Department of Health and Environment (“KDHE”) in which the respondents did not admit liability for the contamination of the Jayhawk plant (previously used by the former Gulf Oil Chemical Company, among others) but agreed to perform certain remedial efforts. In 2006, a “Perimeter Monitoring Program” was established to monitor the site for residual anthropogenic releases that could be related to historical facility operations and to achieve the site monitoring objectives requested by the KDHE. Compounds historically associated with the Jayhawk site include nitrates, VOCs and perchlorate. The KDHE accepted this risk-based perimeter monitoring approach with no additional investigation or remediation required at the Jayhawk site as long as the receptors (the relevant bodies of water) remain unimpacted (in accordance with appropriate regulatory standards). Most of our sites are also located on so-called “Industrial Parks”. Such Industrial Parks are operated by the respective owner of each plot of land, who provides a regular environmental soil assessment of the land to the companies located thereon (one of which is us) and who are responsible for the environmental management of the residual pollution. Our Knapsack and Gersthofen facilities are located in Industrial Parks that contain historic residual soil contamination. As such, we may incur significant additional monitoring and/or clean-up costs as a result of additional contamination discovered, additional contamination due to a natural disaster event or additional remedial obligations imposed in the future. Moreover, we may also be jointly and severally liable for environmental and health-related damages caused by one or more of our legal predecessors or related to assets acquired by us or them, regardless of fault. Such discovery of previously unknown contamination, or the imposition of new obligations to investigate or remediate soil or groundwater contamination, at our facilities could result in substantial unanticipated costs to us. In addition, operators of Industrial Parks are also responsible for its infrastructure, for example, maintenance of energy supply infrastructure (e.g., electrical lines) or retention basins for waste water, which are used by all companies located thereon. Any disruptions of an Industrial Park’s infrastructure might affect our operations. Similarly, we might be exposed to incidents at neighboring companies beyond our control at Industrial Parks which might lead to temporary interruptions of our business operations, such as, for example, outages in our steam supply or the timely implementation of a new wastewater treatment facility in Pratteln through an outsourcing solution which is required by Swiss authorities. See “⸺Risks Related _to the Industry in Which We Operate⸺We are subject to stringent environmental, health and safety laws and regulations across multiple jurisdictions. We are highly regulated and may incur significant costs to maintain compliance with, or address liabilities under, environmental, health and safety laws and regulations applicable to our business.”_ Should any of the above factors occur, this may result in an increase in our costs and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Environmental and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: The emission of carbon dioxide is subject to a constantly developing body of laws and regulatory requirements addressing the challenges of global climate change by reducing emissions, promoting higher efficiency in the use of energy from conventional sources and increasing the use of energy from renewable sources. Changes in the law or the price of emission allowances, or other climate related regulatory requirements, may affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: At the international level, the Paris Agreement is the first agreement that includes an obligation to keep the global temperature within a specific range, namely “well below” 2.0 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Since the entry into force of this Agreement in late 2016, and with the recent increase of natural disasters, governmental efforts to tackle 44 ----- climate change have grown globally. This goes hand in hand with the adoption of climate change legislation, relating in particular to greenhouse gas emissions and energy use and consumption. Given that the actions envisaged so far by the signatory states to the Paris Agreement were considered not to be sufficient at the last Conference of the Parties in November 2022, we expect that further legislation will be adopted and existing legislation will become more stringent over the next years. In the European Union, numerous pieces of legislation will be revised in the course of the implementation of the “EU Green Deal” and the “Fit-for-55” package, which will impose additional obligations on us, in particular relating to greenhouse gas emissions and energy efficiency. In the European Union, regulations attempt to both reduce greenhouse gas emissions and to establish a mechanism for trading in carbon dioxide emission allowances. The EU Emission Trading System (“EU ETS”) imposes an EU-wide emissions cap applying to the total amount of greenhouse gas emissions that can be emitted by in-scope operations and provides for the trade with allowances for such emissions. Operators can buy allowances when they are put on the market by EU member states via auctions or on the secondary market. Certain sectors, in relation to which the EU sees a risk that operators would relocate their production site outside the EU where they obliged to buy allowances, can to a certain extent benefit from free allocation. In recent discussions to revise the EU ETS, the relevant EU institutions agreed however, that, for a number of sectors free allocation will be phased out gradually over the coming years. Instead, those sectors will be subject to the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism. This means that EU manufacturers will need to buy allowances for their emissions, but that importers from outside the EU will likewise need to buy carbon certificates, corresponding to the carbon price that they would have paid if they had manufactured the products in the EU. Under the currently applicable ETS, the EUwide emissions cap is lowered annually by a linear factor of 1.74% of the average annual total quantity of emission allowances issued in the EU in the second trading period. In the recent discussions to revise the EU ETS, the relevant EU institutions agreed on a one-off reduction of the EU-wide quantity of allowances by 90 million in 2024 and by 27 million in 2026 respectively and on an annual reduction of the overall cap by 4.3% from 2024 to 27 and by 4.4% from 2028 to 2030. Although we have not been required to date to acquire emission allowances for our covered operations, as the amount of our emissions does not exceed the thresholds that cause the applicability of the ETS, we cannot predict with certainty whether those thresholds may be decreased and/or what applicable thresholds in the future may be. If we were required in the future to purchase emission allowances in the amount required for our production purposes, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Furthermore, as a result of these changes in regulation, there have been several social movements in Europe (for example the Farm to Fork Strategy) encouraging restaurants to source their ingredients from local farms or encourage consumers to eat only locally grown foods. Such trends could potentially lead to a decrease in demand for herbicides and pesticides which could ultimately adversely impact our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. In the United States, the EPA is engaged in ongoing GHG rulemaking. In light of legislative and judicial challenges to EPA action, significant uncertainty currently exists as to how GHG regulations will in the future impact large stationary sources, including any facilities we operate or in the future may operate in the U.S., and what costs or operational changes these regulations may require. In August 2022, the U.S. Congress passed, and President Biden signed into law, the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022, which appropriates significant federal funding for renewable energy initiatives and, for the first time ever, imposes a fee on methane emissions from certain facilities. In addition, the U.S. Congress has from time to time considered legislation to reduce emissions of GHGs. In the absence of such federal climate legislation, a significant number of U.S. states have taken legal measures to reduce emissions of GHGs, including through the development of GHG emission inventories and/or regional GHG gas cap-and-trade programs. It is difficult to predict the form for such regulation that the U.S. Congress or U.S. states may adopt in the future (e.g., a cap-and-trade program, technology mandate, emissions tax or other regulatory mechanism) or, consequently, estimate any costs that we may be required to incur in respect of such requirements. For example, with respect to facilities we operate or may operate in the United States, we could be required to install emissions control equipment, purchase emissions allowances, administer and manage our GHG emissions program, or address other regulatory obligations, which may adversely impact our operations, financial condition and cash flows. Additional future regulation of GHGs in the United States could result from future international treaty obligations, regulatory changes under the CAA or other existing legislation, or federal, state or regional adoption of GHG regulatory schemes. For example, in March 2022, the SEC proposed new rules relating to the disclosure of a range of climate-related data risks and opportunities, including financial impacts, physical and transition risks, related governance and strategy and GHG emissions, for certain public companies. We are currently assessing this rule but at this time we cannot predict the ultimate impact of the rule on our business or those of our customers. 45 ----- In Switzerland, following the rejection of a proposed revision of the CO2 Act (Bundesgesetz über die Reduktion _der CO2-Emissionen, CO2-Gesetz) in a popular referendum in June 2021, the Swiss Federal Council has_ published a new proposal for a revised CO2 Act in September 2022. However, such revision has yet to pass parliament and, potentially, a popular referendum. In the interim, the CO2 Act has been updated to align the reduction target with Switzerland’s international commitments until 2024 and extend certain emissions reduction instruments which would otherwise have expired. In particular, the Swiss emissions trading system continues to apply with the aforementioned update ensuring that emissions reduction certificates not used in 2021 can be transferred to the time period 2022 to 2024. In addition, the Swiss emissions trading system is linked to that of the EU since January 2020. An increase of prices due to reduced number of emissions allowances issued will therefore also impact Swiss participants having to acquire emission allowances. Furthermore, modifications to the Swiss emissions trading systems following those of the EU are currently being evaluated. We are currently assessing the developments around the CO2 Act and potential modifications to the Swiss emissions trading systems but at this time we cannot predict the ultimate impact of the rule on our business or those of our customers.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Environmental and Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Title: If our customers are not able to obtain or maintain the necessary regulatory approvals for some of their products which use our chemical products, this could restrict our ability to sell those products to certain customers.
Subsubsection Text: Within Europe and the United States, the regulatory environment may be impacted by the activities of nongovernmental organizations and special interest groups and stakeholder reaction to actual or perceived impacts of new and existing technology, products or processes on safety, health and the environment. Obtaining and maintaining regulatory approvals requires submitting a significant amount of information and data, which may require participation from technology providers. Regulatory standards and trial procedures are continuously changing. In addition, in recent years within the United States and the European Union, there has been an increase in the number of lawsuits filed by those who identify themselves as public or environmental interest groups seeking to invalidate pesticide product registrations and/or challenge the way federal or state governmental entities apply the rules and regulations governing pesticide produce use. Even though the general predicted trend is in favor of greener agrochemical products, non-environmentally friendly pesticide products associated with older registrations face the increased risk of social and legal challenges, for example, export restrictions on nonregistered products as imposed by the European Union and Switzerland. If in the future there is any unintended regulatory non-compliance by certain of our key customers, this could negatively impact our business and operations. Responding to any potential regulatory changes and meeting existing and new requirements may involve significant costs for certain customers or capital expenditures or require changes in business practice which could ultimately result in our reduced profitability. Failure to receive necessary permits or approvals by our customers could have near- and long-term effects on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We require various licenses and permits to operate our business.
Subsubsection Text: We require various licenses and permits in the jurisdictions in which we operate. These licenses and permits are generally subject to conditions stipulated in the licenses and permits and/or relevant laws or regulations under which such licenses and permits are issued. While we constantly monitor and ensure our compliance with such conditions, any actual or alleged failure to comply with the stipulated conditions could result in the revocation, suspension or non-renewal of the relevant license or permit, or penalties and/or fines. Should there be any revocation, rejection or delay in the issuance of any of the licenses and permits we need, or the failure to obtain or procure any necessary licenses and permits, we may not be able to carry out our operations in the relevant jurisdiction or we may face materially increased costs in our operations so as to find an alternative solution. For example, we are exposed to risks associated with approvals when building and operating production facilities. Relevant regulatory authorities may not grant licenses, approvals, certifications, exemptions and exceptions as quickly as anticipated, which may result in project delays or unused capacities. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to risks related to subsidies under the StromNEV and similar laws.
Subsubsection Text: Our German sites currently benefit each from an arrangement on individual network tariffs with the responsible network operator pursuant to the Electricity Network Tariff Regulation Ordinance (Stromnetzentgeltverordnung, “StromNEV”) which allows reductions of the regular network tariffs for undertakings with high electricity consumption. If the consumption related thresholds are not met by the relevant site in a calendar year, the 46 ----- difference to the regular network tariff must be paid to the network operator for such calendar year retroactively. Therefore, it remains uncertain whether we may have to pay the difference to the full network tariff retroactively or whether the eligibility criteria may be amended in the future, which could result in a partial loss of the individual network tariffs and, consequently, additional expenses. As we operate sites in six countries, we might be exposed to similar risks in the other countries we operate which would adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our confidentiality agreements may not protect our know-how.
Subsubsection Text: The production process for chemicals is complex and requires significant technical expertise. We rely upon unpatented processes and continuing technological innovation and other trade secrets to develop and maintain our competitive position. While it is our policy to enter into confidentiality agreements with our employees and third parties to protect our and our customers’ intellectual property, there can be no assurances that our confidentiality agreements will not be breached or that they will provide meaningful protection for our trade secrets or knowhow, or that adequate remedies will be available in the event of an unauthorized use or disclosure of these trade secrets and know-how. Moreover, there can be no assurance that others will not obtain knowledge of these trade secrets and know-how through independent development or other access by legal means, which could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: If we are sued for infringing intellectual property rights of third parties, it may be costly and time-consuming, and an unfavorable outcome in any litigation could harm our business and reputation.
Subsubsection Text: We cannot assure you that our activities will not, unintentionally or otherwise, infringe on the patents or other intellectual property rights owned by others. We may spend significant time and effort and incur significant litigation costs if we are required to defend ourselves against intellectual property rights claims brought against us, regardless of whether the claims have merit, and such claims and defense may require significant management time and attention that would otherwise be devoted to our business operations. If we are found to have infringed on the patents or other intellectual property rights of others, we may be subject to substantial claims for damages, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We may also be required to cease development, use or sale of the relevant products or processes, or we may be required to obtain a license on the disputed rights, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. The involvement in any process for alleged infringement of intellectual property, regardless of whether the claims have merit, may harm our business and reputation.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We must comply with foreign trade laws, sanctions, anti-bribery, anti-trust, anti-money laundering and anti- corruption laws across the jurisdictions in which we operate.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to anti-corruption, anti-bribery, anti-trust, anti-money laundering laws and economic sanctions programs in all jurisdictions in which we operate, including such laws and regulations imposed by the European Union, the United States and the United Nations (in each case to the extent applicable). In particular, our international operations expose us to potential liability under the United States Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977, any law, rule or regulation promulgated to implement the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development’s (“OECD”) Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials in International Business Transactions, signed 17 December 1997, and other similar laws and regulations relating to anticorruption, the anti-boycott regulations administered by the U.S. Department of Commerce's Office of Antiboycott Compliance and economic sanction programs administered by the U.S. Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control (“OFAC”) and corresponding regimes administered by the European Union. Economic sanctions programs do and will continue to restrict the Group’s ability to engage in business dealings with certain sanctioned countries. There is no certainty that our employees, representatives and agents will comply with all applicable laws and regulations, particularly given the complexity of these laws and the potential corporate structure of customers. Some of the international locations in which we operate, in particular China, have legal systems different from those in our home jurisdictions and some may have higher than normal levels of corruption. As a result, there can be no assurance that our policies and procedures will effectively prevent us or our employees, representatives and agents from violating these laws and regulations in every transaction in which we may engage. Furthermore, it is possible that certain foreign trade policies may be construed or applied in a manner that is adverse to us, unforeseen, or otherwise inconsistent with our practices. Non-compliance with foreign trade laws may lead to fines, penalties, substantial reputational damage as well as the overall or partial shut-down of our 47 ----- shipping activities which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Any failure to effectively prevent, identify or address breaches of our legal obligations as a result of inadequate internal controls, compliance management and risk management systems could result in administrative, civil and criminal sanctions, the assertion of damages claims by third parties and reputational damage, each of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We do not have any direct revenue exposure to Russia or Ukraine; however, we are aware that some of our customers subsequently distribute our products or incorporate our products into the production of their goods which, in certain circumstances, are distributed, and may continue to be distributed in the future, into Russia or Ukraine in reliance upon exemptions from sanctions in the crop protection and pharmaceuticals markets. However, the continued military incursion by Russia into Ukraine (beginning in February 2022) could adversely impact macroeconomic conditions, give rise to regional instability and result in heightened economic sanctions from the United States and the international community in a manner that could adversely affect our operations in the broader Western European region, including to the extent that any such sanctions restrict our ability to conduct business internationally, develop future opportunities and/or to utilize certain banking systems at our election. Although historically we have not conducted operations in Russia or in Ukraine and we have not derived a material amount of revenue from operations in such jurisdictions, further escalation of geopolitical tensions could have a broader impact that expands into other markets where we do business, including Europe, the United States and Asia Pacific, which may adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to risks from legal and arbitration proceedings, including litigation related expenses and/or reputational damage, among other losses, which could harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we are involved in litigation and other tax, labor, settlement and legal proceedings. We cannot predict with certainty the cost of defense, the cost of prosecution or the ultimate outcome of litigation and other proceedings that may be filed by or against us, including remedies, settlement amounts or damage awards, and adverse results in any litigation and other proceedings may materially harm our business. Litigation and other proceedings may include, but are not limited to, actions relating to intellectual property, commercial arrangements, raw material or energy supply, environmental, health and safety, joint venture agreements and labor and employment matters, as well as other harms resulting from the actions of individuals or entities outside of our control. Litigation based on environmental matters or human exposure to hazardous substances in the workplace or from our products could result in significant liability for us. In the event of a negative outcome in any material legal proceeding, whether based on a judgment or a settlement agreement, we could be obliged to make substantial payments. We currently maintain product liability insurance to cover our liability risks consistent with industry practice. However, there can be no assurance that a successful product liability or other claim would be adequately covered by our applicable insurance policies or by any applicable contractual indemnity or liability limitations. Even if there is a positive outcome to such proceedings, negative publicity and advisory costs, to the extent they are not reimbursable by other litigants or insurance, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Furthermore, our products have widespread uses in a variety of end-markets, including transportation, consumer products and pharmaceuticals. If a product liability claim or series of claims arising out of these various uses (particularly where the value of such claims is in excess of our insurance coverage, applicable indemnification agreements, or any provision we made), were successful against us, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We could be required to increase our debt or divert resources from other investments in our business in order to discharge any such claims, or might not be able to cover such claims at all. Additionally, new determinations about the safety of our products may be made in the future and such determinations may lead to a substantial decline of the sale of any affected products, both of which could materially affect the profitability of our operations. More generally, in the chemicals industry, products, raw materials, and operations are subject to public scrutiny from investors, customers, and activist groups and may become the target of negative publicity or protests and campaigns by public interest groups relating to environmental, health and safety concerns, which, in turn, could lead the public to develop a negative perception of certain of our operations and products, which could materially affect sales and volumes of our products or result in negative regulatory developments. 48 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile
Subsubsection Title: Our substantial leverage and debt service obligations could adversely affect our business and prevent us from fulfilling our obligations with respect to the Notes and the Notes Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: After the issuance of the Notes, we will be highly leveraged. As of December 31, 2022, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions and the application of the proceeds therefrom, we would have had total financial indebtedness of €697.2 million. See “Capitalization.” The degree to which we will be leveraged following the issuance of the Notes could have important consequences to Holders of the Notes offered hereby, including, but not limited to: - making it difficult for us to satisfy our obligations with respect to the Notes; - making us vulnerable to, and reducing our flexibility to respond to, general adverse economic and industry conditions; - requiring the dedication of a substantial portion of our cash flow from operations to the payment of principal of, and interest on, indebtedness, thereby reducing the availability of such cash flow to fund working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint ventures, or other general corporate purposes; - limiting our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business and the competitive environment and the industry in which we operate; - placing us at a competitive disadvantage as compared to our competitors, to the extent that they are not as highly leveraged; and - limiting our ability to borrow additional funds and increasing the cost of any such borrowing. Any of these or other consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy our debt obligations, including the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile
Subsubsection Title: Despite our substantial leverage, we may still be able to incur substantially more debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the Notes, and impair our ability to operate our business.
Subsubsection Text: The terms of the Indenture will permit the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries to incur additional indebtedness, including in respect of committed borrowings of up to €110 million under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement. We may incur additional debt in the future, some of which may rank pari passu with the Notes and the Notes Guarantees, be structurally senior to the Notes and the Notes Guarantees, or be secured by assets that do not form part of the Collateral for the Notes and the Notes Guarantees. Any such additional indebtedness could also mature prior to the Notes. We may also enter into a qualified receivables financing program which would allow us to pledge our receivables that either do not form part of the Collateral or would be released from any security interests in respect of such receivables. Although the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and the Indenture will contain restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, these restrictions are subject to a number of significant qualifications and exceptions, and under certain circumstances the amount of indebtedness that could be incurred in compliance with these restrictions could be substantial. In addition, the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and the Indenture will not prevent us from incurring obligations that do not constitute indebtedness under those agreements. Furthermore, if we are able to designate some of our restricted subsidiaries under the Indenture as unrestricted subsidiaries, those unrestricted subsidiaries would be permitted to borrow beyond the limitations specified in the Indenture and engage in other activities in which restricted subsidiaries may not engage. See “Description of the Notes” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—New _Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement.” If new debt is added to our and our subsidiaries’ existing debt levels, the_ related risks that we now face would increase.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to restrictive debt covenants that may limit our ability to finance future operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will restrict, among other things, our ability to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or incur certain liens; 49 ----- - make certain payments, including dividends or other distributions, with respect to the shares of such entity; - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity; - make certain investments; - create encumbrances or restrictions on the payment of dividends or other distributions, loans or advances to, and on the transfer of, assets to such entity; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets, including stock of restricted subsidiaries; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - consolidate or merge with other entities; - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes; and - (in case of the Issuer only) engage in activities other than certain permitted holding company activities. All of these limitations will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes— _Certain Covenants.” Despite these exceptions and qualifications, the covenants to which we are subject could_ limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and our ability to pursue business opportunities and activities that may be in our interest. In addition, we will be subject to the affirmative and negative covenants contained in the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement. A breach of any of those covenants or the occurrence of certain specified events will, subject to applicable cure periods and other limitations, result in an event of default under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement. Upon the occurrence of any event of default under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, the Acceleration Majority Lenders (being, subject to certain limitations, lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement whose commitments thereunder aggregate more than 66 [2]/3% of the total commitments thereunder) could, while such event of default remains unremedied or unwaived, cancel the availability of the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and elect to declare all amounts outstanding under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, together with accrued interest, immediately due and payable. In addition, a default or event of default under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement could lead to an event of default and acceleration under other debt instruments that contain cross-default or cross-acceleration provisions, including the Indenture. If our creditors, including the creditors under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, accelerate the payment of amounts owing to them under such other debt instruments, we cannot assure you that our assets and the assets of our subsidiaries would be sufficient to repay in full those amounts, to satisfy all our other liabilities and the liabilities of our subsidiaries which would be due and payable and to make payments to enable us to repay the Notes, in full or in part. In addition, if we are unable to repay those amounts, our creditors could proceed against any security interests granted to them to secure repayment of those amounts.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to generate sufficient cash to service our indebtedness and may be forced to take other actions to meet our obligations under our indebtedness, which may not be successful.
Subsubsection Text: We are highly leveraged and have significant debt service obligations. Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on our indebtedness, including our drawings under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and our obligations under the Notes, and to fund our ongoing operations, will depend on our future performance and our ability to generate cash, which, to a certain extent, is subject to general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, legal and regulatory factors discussed in these “Risk Factors” as well as elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, as well as other factors, many of which are beyond our control. Our New Revolving Credit Facility will mature in 2027 and the Notes will mature in 2028. See “Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes.” At the maturity of loans outstanding under the_ New Revolving Credit Facility and of the obligations under the Notes and any other debt which we incur, if we do not have sufficient cash flows from operations and other capital resources to pay our debt obligations, or to fund our other liquidity needs, or we are otherwise restricted from doing so due to corporate, tax or contractual limitations, we may be required to refinance our indebtedness. If we are unable to refinance all or a portion of our indebtedness or obtain such refinancing on terms acceptable to us, we may be forced to reduce or delay our 50 ----- business obligations, activities or capital expenditures, sell assets, raise additional debt or equity financing in amounts that could be substantial, or restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity. We cannot guarantee that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all, or that those actions would secure sufficient funds to meet our obligations under our indebtedness. In particular, our ability to restructure or refinance our debt will depend in part on our financial condition at such time as well as on many factors outside of our control, including then prevailing conditions in the international credit and capital markets. Any refinancing of our debt could be at higher interest rates than our current debt and may require us to comply with more onerous covenants. The terms of existing or future debt instruments and the Indenture and the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement may restrict us from adopting some of these alternatives. In addition, any failure to make payments of interest or principal on our outstanding indebtedness on a timely basis would likely result in a reduction of our credit rating, which could harm our ability to incur additional indebtedness. In addition, we use a Securitization Program and a Factoring Program to meet some of our liquidity requirements and are subject to various covenants thereunder. If we fail to comply with these covenants, a default may occur and we may need to fund our working capital requirements from other sources. In the absence of operating results and resources sufficient to service our indebtedness we could face substantial liquidity problems and might be required to dispose of material assets or operations to meet our debt service and other obligations. The terms of our indebtedness, including the terms of the Indenture and the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, will restrict our ability to transfer or sell assets and the use of proceeds from any such disposal. We may not be able to carry out certain disposals or to obtain the funds that we could have realized from the proceeds of such dispositions, and any proceeds we do realize from asset dispositions may not be adequate to meet any of our debt service obligations then due. These alternative measures may not be successful and may not permit us to meet our debt service obligations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile
Subsubsection Title: Drawings under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and the Floating Rate Notes will bear interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, increasing our costs and reducing cash flows.
Subsubsection Text: Drawings under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and the Floating Rate Notes will, and future indebtedness that we may incur could, bear interest at floating rates of interest per annum equal to EURIBOR, compounded SARON or term SOFR (as applicable) or other benchmarks, plus a spread. These interest rates could rise significantly in the future, thereby increasing our interest expenses associated with these obligations, reducing cash flow available for capital expenditures and hindering our ability to make payments on the Notes. Although we may enter into and maintain certain hedging arrangements designed to fix a portion of these rates, there can be no assurance that hedging will be available or continue to be available on commercially reasonable terms. Hedging itself carries certain risks, including that we may need to pay a significant amount (including costs) to terminate any hedging arrangements. To the extent interest rates were to rise significantly, our interest expense would correspondingly increase, thus reducing cash flow.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile
Subsubsection Title: EURIBOR or other benchmarks may be discontinued or change in the future.
Subsubsection Text: Various interest rate benchmarks (including historic EURIBOR) have been the subject of recent national and international regulatory guidance and proposals for reform. Some reforms are already effective, including the EU Benchmark Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/1011), while others are still to be implemented. EURIBOR has been subject to recent reform to comply with the relevant regulatory requirements of a critical benchmark, and there are no present plans to replace it with an alternative rate. However, similar future reforms and other pressures may cause EURIBOR or other such benchmarks to disappear entirely, to perform differently than in the past (as a result of a change in methodology or otherwise), create disincentives for market participants to continue to administer or participate in certain benchmarks or have other consequences which cannot be predicted. Based on the foregoing, you should in particular be aware that (a) any of these reforms or pressures or any other changes to a relevant interest rate benchmark, as well as manipulative practices or the cessation thereof, could affect the level of the published rate, including to cause a sudden or prolonged increase and/or to make it more volatile than it would otherwise be, which could have an adverse impact on our ability to service debt that bears interest at floating rates of interest, and (b) if EURIBOR (or any of their successors or other benchmarks) is discontinued, that may require amendments to the Indenture and the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement or other documentation that references such rate and, in relation to any of our obligations which have not 51 ----- transitioned to a successor rate by the relevant date, then the rate of interest applicable to such obligations may be determined for a period by applicable fallback provisions, specified in the relevant documentation for such obligations, although such provisions, if they are dependent in part upon the provision by reference banks of offered quotations, may not operate as intended (depending on market circumstances and the availability of rates information at the relevant time). In addition, the development of future alternatives to EURIBOR may result in the Floating Rate Notes performing differently than would otherwise have been the case if the alternatives to EURIBOR had not developed. The Indenture will provide a mechanism whereby, if EURIBOR is no longer being calculated or administered, the Issuer could, in consultation with an independent financial advisor, determine an appropriate successor rate, which means that interest on the Floating Rate Notes would be determined on the basis of a benchmark rate, together with adjustments, that was not contemplated at the time you purchased the Floating Rate Notes issued on or about the Issue Date. See “Description of the Notes—Principal, Maturity and Interest.” The Indenture may require the exercise of discretion by the Issuer and the making of potentially subjective judgments (including as to the occurrence or not of any events which may trigger amendments to the Indenture) without the consent of the holders of the Floating Rate Notes. The interests of the Issuer in making such determinations or amendments may be adverse to the interests of the holders of the Floating Rate Notes. In addition, due to the uncertainty concerning the availability of an appropriate successor rate and the involvement of an independent financial institution, the Indenture’s successor rate mechanism may not operate as intended at the relevant time. Any elimination of the EURIBOR benchmark, or changes in the manner of administration of EURIBOR, could require an adjustment to the terms and conditions of our floating rate debt. Any such consequence could have a material adverse effect on the value of and return on any such floating rate debt. If EURIBOR were discontinued or otherwise unavailable, the rate of interest on our floating rate debt will be determined for the relevant period by the fallback provisions applicable to such debt.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Holders of the Notes will not control certain decisions regarding the Collateral and other distressed disposals.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured initially on a first priority basis by the same Collateral securing the obligations under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and certain cash management obligations, if any, and certain hedging obligations, if any. In addition, under the terms of the Indenture, we will be permitted to incur significant additional indebtedness and other obligations that may be secured by the same Collateral on a pari passu or on a super priority basis. Pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement, lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, providers of certain additional indebtedness, certain cash management obligations, if any, and certain hedging obligations, if any, the Security Agent, any receiver and certain creditor representatives are entitled to be repaid with the proceeds of the Collateral sold in any enforcement sale in priority to the Notes. As such, in the event of a foreclosure of the Collateral or any other distressed disposal, you may not be able to recover on the Collateral if the aggregate of the then outstanding claims under super senior indebtedness are greater than or equal to the proceeds realized. Any proceeds from an enforcement sale of the Collateral by any creditor will, after all obligations under super senior indebtedness have been discharged from such recoveries, be applied _pro rata in repayment of the Notes, any other obligations secured by the Collateral which are permitted to rank _pari passu with the Notes and certain cash management obligations, if any, and certain hedging obligations, if any, that do not rank on a super-senior basis. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that a common Security Agent, who will also serve as the security agent for the lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, the cash management and hedging obligations that are permitted by the Indenture to be secured on the Collateral, and any additional debt secured by the Collateral permitted to be incurred by the Indenture will act only as provided for in the Intercreditor Agreement and the Security Documents. The Intercreditor Agreement regulates the ability of the Trustee or the holders of the Notes to instruct the Security Agent to take enforcement action. The Security Agent is not required to take enforcement action unless instructed to do so by an Instructing Group (as defined below under “Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”) that comprises (i) creditors holding in aggregate_ more than 66[2]/3% of the aggregate commitments under the New Revolving Credit Facility, the aggregate commitments under any super senior credit facility and the aggregate of hedging exposures under certain priority hedging obligations and exposures under certain cash management facilities (the “Majority Super Senior

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Creditors”) and (ii) creditors holding in aggregate more than 50% of the outstanding principal amount of the
Subsubsection Text: Notes and the outstanding principal amount of any indebtedness ranking pari passu with the Notes (the “Majority 52 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Senior Secured Creditors”) (in each case acting through their respective creditor representative). If, however,
Subsubsection Title: Certain Collateral will not initially secure the Notes and the Subsidiary Guarantors will not initially guarantee the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: On or about the Issue Date, the Notes and the Issue Date Guarantees will be secured by the Issue Date Collateral. Pursuant to the terms of the Indenture, we will be required to take such necessary actions so that, consistent with the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, on or about the Issue Date (or, in any case, no later than 120 days after the Issue Date), the Notes and the Notes Guarantees are secured, to the extent not already so secured, by the applicable Collateral, which will also secure the New Revolving Credit Facility subject to the Agreed Security Principles. There can, however, be no assurance that we will be successful in procuring such liens within the time period specified, if at all. In addition, on or about the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by CABB Group GmbH. Pursuant to the terms of the Indenture, we will be required to take such necessary actions so that, substantially consistent with the New Revolving Credit Facility within 120 days of the Issue Date and the Notes are also guaranteed, on a senior basis with respect to the Notes by the Subsidiary Guarantors. There can, however, be no assurance that the Subsidiary Guarantors will provide their relevant guarantees within the time period specified, if at all.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Senior Secured Creditors”) (in each case acting through their respective creditor representative). If, however,
Subsubsection Title: The Collateral may not be sufficient to secure the obligations under the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured by security interests in the Collateral described in this Offering Memorandum, which Collateral also secures the obligations under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, certain additional indebtedness and certain hedging obligations, if any and cash management obligations, if any. Upon a refinancing of the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, or if the lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement consent to an increase of the commitments under the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, the amount that will benefit from first priority security interest in the Collateral may be increased up to the amount provided under the Indenture. The Collateral may also secure additional debt ranking pari passu with the Notes to the extent permitted by the terms of the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement. The rights of the holders of the Notes to the Collateral may therefore be diluted by any increase in the obligations secured by the Collateral or a reduction of the Collateral securing the Notes. The value of the Collateral and the amount to be received upon an enforcement of such Collateral will depend upon many factors, including, among others, the ability to sell the Collateral in an orderly sale, the condition of the economies in which our operations are located and the availability of buyers. The book value of the Collateral 53 ----- should not be relied on as a measure of realizable value for such assets. All or a portion of the Collateral may be illiquid and may have no readily ascertainable market value. Likewise, we cannot assure you that there will be a market for the sale of the Collateral, or, if such a market exists, that there will not be a substantial delay in our liquidation. In addition, the share pledges over the shares of an entity may be of no value if that entity is subject to an insolvency or bankruptcy proceeding. The Collateral is located in Germany, Finland, Switzerland, Luxembourg and the United States, and the multi-jurisdictional nature of any foreclosure on the Collateral may limit the realizable value of the Collateral. For example, the bankruptcy, insolvency, administrative and other laws of the various jurisdictions may be materially different from, or conflict with, each other, including in the areas of rights of creditors, priority of government and other creditors, ability to obtain post-petition interest and duration of the proceedings.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Senior Secured Creditors”) (in each case acting through their respective creditor representative). If, however,
Subsubsection Title: The granting of the security interests in connection with the issuance of the Notes, or the incurrence of permitted debt in the future, may create or restart hardening periods, i.e., the periods of time following the granting of security interests during which such security interests may be challenged in accordance with the laws applicable in certain jurisdictions.
Subsubsection Text: The granting of security interests to secure the Notes and the Notes Guarantees may create hardening periods for such security interests in certain jurisdictions.
