Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading CDMO (contract development and manufacturing organization) and fine chemistry manufacturer with global operations, supplying customized ingredients to major players in the Western Crop Science market, as well as high purity and high-complexity chemical ingredients to customers in the Life Science and Performance Material markets. Our strong technology portfolio, technical know-how and execution capabilities allow us to cover a wide spectrum of highly specialized customer needs, specifications and complexity profiles. Headquartered in Germany, we operate a global network with six production facilities located in Pratteln (Switzerland), Kokkola (Finland), Galena (Kansas, United States), Gersthofen (Germany), Knapsack (Germany) and Jining, Shandong Province (China). Our varied product portfolio is organized across two product groups: (i) Exclusives (tailor-made active ingredients and precursors developed for individual customers on an exclusive basis (our CDMO offering)) and Specialties (highly specialized ingredients with applications in high-margin end-markets) products and (ii) Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals products (intermediate and base chemical products such as high purity monochloroacetic acid (“MCA”), chloroacetyl chloride (“CAC1”) and caustic soda across a large purity spectrum with multiple end-use applications). Our products are deeply embedded into our customers’ value chains, often on a near-exclusive basis, allowing us to be aligned in demand planning and supply chain coordination and to set up scalable manufacturing facilities and efficient commercial production processes. The combination of our production know-how, lengthy product development processes and contractually agreed capital expenditure contributions for some of our products typically result in high contract renewal rates and low customer churn. For the financial year ended December 31, 2022, we generated revenue of €755.5 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of €162.6 million (21.5% Adjusted EBITDA margin). Between 2020 and 2022, our revenue grew at 23.9% CAGR, whereas our Adjusted EBITDA grew at 20.0% CAGR. Exclusives and Specialties contributed to 56.8% of our revenue for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 whereas Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals accounted for 43.2% of our revenue for the same period. Our products are used for end-market applications mainly in: (i) Crop Science (e.g., herbicides, fungicides, insecticides and other livestock and crop protection products), (ii) Life Science (e.g., pharma, personal care, nutrition, fragrances and flavor applications) and (iii) Performance Materials (e.g., curatives in epoxies, polyimides, polyesters and other resin systems used for electronic components, semiconductors and for composites, fibers, films, and foams that provide heat and electrical resistance). These end-markets, in particular Crop Science, have shown resilient historical growth rates and benefit from structural mega-trends that are expected to drive further resilient growth in the near- to mid-term, such as increasing demand for food and need for increased farming yields on the one hand, and an aging population and improving living standards on the other. In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of our products were used in the Crop Science market, approximately 20% in the Life Science market, approximately 15% in the Performance Materials market and approximately 15% relate to others (e.g., base chemicals and industrial MCA) (measured as a percentage of revenues). 67 ----- Exclusives, our CDMO offering, provides tailor-made active ingredients and precursors tailored to individual customer specifications in Crop Science and are a primary contributor to our overall profitability. Based on customer-developed IP, these products require customized production lines, expansive know-how and close cooperation with our customers. We offer development and manufacturing services for proprietary products on an exclusive and confidential basis to leading players in the Crop Science market such as: BASF, Bayer, Corteva and Syngenta, and we have relationships with nearly all major players in the Western Crop Science market. Our Specialties offering consists of specialty ingredients that leverage our considerable manufacturing expertise to create complex chemical products that serve specific customer needs across a variety of applications in the Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials industries. Unlike Exclusives, these products can be offered to multiple customers at a time. Our offering highlights our excellent production capabilities and knowhow along with our ability to offer specialized technology process and development services which allows us to continuously provide high-quality and purity products to our customers and which we believe is a key differentiator in this field. Our Specialties products are also a strong contributor to profitability, leveraging our close client relationship and high customer “stickiness”. In particular, we offer high value-add products for fastgrowing applications in Life Science (pharma and personal care as well as nutrition) and Performance Materials markets (coatings, e.g., in electronics or other industrial applications), backed by several attractive long-term customer contracts, which offer high visibility on the lifecycle and returns on our products. Customers for our Specialties products include players such as Agilent Technologies, Bayer, Corteva, Deciem/Estee Lauder, DSM, Evonik, Merck, Novartis and Syngenta. In our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals product group, we offer intermediate and base chemical products, such as MCA, CAC1 and caustic soda, that serve as chemical building blocks for other secondary chemical processes with a variety of applications across a large number of industries and markets. We believe we are one of the leading suppliers of MCA to Western Europe and the Americas and we operate state-of-the-art sites, allowing us to provide a full range of purity and quality for our customers. Large parts of our Advanced Intermediates supply agreements feature price formulas that allow us to partially pass on price increases in costs of certain raw materials. Furthermore, we also generate a portion of our revenue from Base Chemicals and other products such as caustic soda, that are generated as by-products from our Exclusives and Advanced Intermediates production lines.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Development of mega-trends in the Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials markets
Subsubsection Text: _Crop Science market_ In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 50% of our products were used in the Crop Science market (measured as a percentage of revenues). Accordingly, with our focus on the Crop Science market, our results of operations are affected by changes in the market environment and the demand for our products by our customers. In particular, the underlying global Crop Science market growth is driven by megatrends such as a growing population driving demand for food and crops and decreasing arable land per capita, requiring efficient crop protection products to increase farming yields. Our results are also affected by trends in the addressable CDMO Crop Science market such as a growth in CDMO outsourcing and increasing complexity of active ingredient molecules requiring specialist CDMO partners with strong technical expertise and assets fitting into global supply chains of Crop Science players (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). From 2019 to 2022, the underlying global Crop Science market grew at a CAGR of 7.8% from €55.6 billion to €69.6 billion due to trends such as favorable weather conditions, increased crop prices as well as increased manufacturing and logistics costs partially passed through with the product price (Roland Berger Report). See “Industry and Market Data⸺Crop Science⸺General⸺Key Drivers.” Herbicides, fungicides and insecticides, for which we supply tailor-made products, as well as high-quality intermediates, to our customers, play an essential role in crop protection and result in higher productivity per acre (higher crop yields). In 2022, herbicides, the largest sub-segment of the underlying global Crop Science market, accounted for approximately 40%. Insecticides accounted for approximately 30%, fungicides for approximately 28% and others (e.g. plant growth regulators) approximately 3% of the market. The majority of the different segments are expected to grow with a CAGR between 2% and 3% until 2027, with the exception of herbicides, which is expected to grow at a CAGR of less than 1% between 2022 and 2027. Overall, the global Crop Science market growth is expected at a CAGR of 2% between 2022 and 2027 (Roland Berger Report, AgbioInvestor). 68 ----- _Life Science market_ In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 20% of our products were used in the Life Science market (measured as a percentage of revenues). We have considerable manufacturing power for chemical products aimed for the Life Science market. However, our results of operations are affected by macroeconomic changes in the Life Science market and the ultimate demand for our customers’ products. See “Risk _Factors⸺Risks Related to the Industry in Which we Operate⸺Economic downturns or worsening global economic conditions may adversely impact our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows”_ and “⸺Changes in our customers’ products or processes can reduce the demand for our products.” Markets for Life Science products served by us showed varying growth rates between 2019 and 2022. Our targeted Life Science market segments also include several fast-growing niche products such as DCA, which significantly increased in size during the same period. The addressable Life Science market growth is driven by supportive developments in specific segments with a high demand for specialty products, such as novel RNA therapeutics, vitamins and supplements, as well as a rising adoption in skin care products. In addition, the Life Science market is further positively impacted by certain mega-trends such as a global aging population, together with an increasing disposable income spent on health and personal care. Our customers include some of the largest established market brands in the cosmetics (including anti-aging products), vitamin and supplements industries. Our top products comprise Monochloroacetic acid (“MCA”), Dichloroacetic acid (“DCA”), Glycolic acid (“GA”) and Ethyl-2chloroacetoacetate (“CAE”), each with several high-value applications across the Life Science market. In personal care, our high purity MCA acts as basis for Betaine synthesis used, e.g., for shampoos, toothpaste or synthetic caffeine. In addition, we are the global market leader and only large-scale Western supplier of high purity grade DCA (a key ingredient for RNA-based medication) in Life Science for pharmaceutical applications (by high purity DCA revenue as of 2022). In cosmetic grade GA, we are globally the second largest supplier (measured by revenue as of 2022) and the only European producer with global coverage. In the vitamins market, CAE produced in our plants is used as the basis for Vitamin B6 synthesis that are further applied in, for example, nutrition (Company assessment based on the Roland Berger Report). See “Industry and Market Data⸺Life Science⸺General.” _Performance Materials market_ Alongside our operations in the Crop Science and Life Science markets, our results of operations are also driven by changes in the global Performance Materials market and the demand for our products by our customers. In 2022, based on internal assessments, we estimate that approximately 15% of our products were used in the Performance Materials market (measured as a percentage of revenues). High Performance Materials are increasingly needed by suppliers to manufacture their complex products, with our chemicals being used in, among others, flexible printed circuitry and foldable displays for smart devices, composite components for automotive and aviation, thermal insulation for aircraft and marine vessels, coatings and tubing for medical devices and radiation shielding for spacecraft. See “Industry and Market _Data⸺Performance Materials⸺Specialty Anhydrides⸺General.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Individual product volumes and margins as well as our product mix are key drivers to maintaining and enhancing our profitability. We hold strong market positions across certain of our product groups in the Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials markets. We believe that we are among the top two Western CDMO players in the Crop Science market (by Crop Science CDMO revenue as of 2021). The active ingredients and precursors that we supply to our Crop Science customers are used in the production of herbicides, fungicides and insecticides. Demand for these products and therefore the volumes that we sell may vary from year to year based on, amongst others, external factors such as weather conditions in different parts of the world and prevailing crop prices, which in turn can impact our margins. Our key Crop Science customers are active on a global scale and our sales to them are oftentimes based on longer-term contracts. Moreover, being a specialized CDMO is a service business, most of our Exclusives products are tailored to an individual customer’s specific requirements based on their intellectual property and, therefore, critical to the production or performance of our customers’ products. In addition, our portfolio comprises innovative products in niche markets with high growth rates, such as DCA (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). We are one of the largest European Life Science MCA suppliers (by production volume in Europe as of 2022). We are the global market leader and only large-scale Western supplier of high purity grade DCA (a key ingredient for RNA-based medication) in Life Science for pharmaceutical applications (by high purity DCA revenue as of 2022) (Roland Berger Report, Company Information). See also 69 ----- “⸺Development of mega-trends in the Crop Science, Life Science and Performance Materials Markets” and “Industry and Market Data.” We benefit from the critical nature of certain of our Exclusive and Specialties ingredients to the performance of our customers’ products as well as our high integration into our customers’ value chain, sometimes being the primary supplier of certain key products, which is in such cases embedded into our contractual agreements with our customers. For our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals group, which comprises a number of products, each with a broad range of customers, our business operations are mostly driven by underlying supply and demand market dynamics as well as our plant utilization rates. MCA, as one of our main products in Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals, is mainly used in the Life Science and the Crop Science markets. Historically, demand for MCA has grown across various end-markets, which, we believe, has contributed to our high utilization rates. Furthermore, proximity to customers and supply chain expertise are critical due to the relatively high transportation costs of distributing MCA. We believe we are also able to better serve our customers in this area due to our differentiated logistics capabilities. Our Base Products, such as caustic soda and hydrochloric acid, are by-products from the production of chlorine and MCA, and are used in several end-markets including the broader chemicals space, pulp and paper, alumina, soap, detergents and others. Caustic soda prices are highly volatile due to their strong dependency on chlorine production (which impacts caustic supply, as caustic demand remains relatively stable over time) and energy prices. The market price for caustic soda declined in 2020 and 2021 driven by lower overall economic activity during the pandemic, thereby negatively impacting the contribution of some of our products to our profitability for the 2020 and 2021 financial years, however it subsequently significantly increased in 2022 with prices reaching an all-time high, which had a positive impact on our results which materialized in a significant uplift of revenues in 2022. Since then, the market price of caustic soda has declined to some extent and we expect it to normalize (at approximately €400-600/t, based on Western European spot rates) further in the future (Roland Berger Report, Company Information).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Raw material and energy prices are key components of our cost of sales and therefore are a significant value lever for our gross profit. Our cost of raw materials and supplies was €270.7 million or 47.9% of our cost of sales for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022 (2021: €216.5 million or 47.0% of our cost of sales; 2020: €157.6 million or 40.4% of our cost of sales). The cost of raw materials has generally been correlated with industry wide supply, demand dynamics and global economic conditions. For example, a primary driver for the increase in 2021 and 2022 was due to an increase in certain raw materials prices such as acetic acid. We have a value-added pricing model with partial cost passthrough mechanisms in some of our contracts. Since price volatilities in raw material or energy prices could have a negative impact on our margins, we are highly focused on our ability to partially pass on raw material price changes and our ability to maintain high degree of utilization in our plants. In the Crop Science market in particular, raw materials used in the production of our Exclusives and Specialties products are to a significant extent either provided by our customers and are therefore not recorded in our cost of sales, or some of our customer contracts include partial pass-through clauses to protect against fluctuations in the prices of raw materials, helping to protect against margin fluctuations. For example, in Exclusives, some contracts are conversion fee model based and resulting revenues from most of such contracts were not exposed to any raw material price fluctuations. In such contracts, raw materials are sourced directly through the customers or 100% charged at cost at the end of the production run. For Specialties and Advanced Intermediates products, some of our contracts include partial cost pass-throughs. These partial pass-through provisions help to limit fluctuations in our cost of sales and therefore protecting profitability by allowing us to partially pass on raw material price increases to our customers. For the Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals, our most important raw materials are acetic acid, acetic anhydride and chlorine and certain customer contracts by sales include price formulas that allow for a partial pass-through of price variations (not including chlorine price variations). Alongside raw material costs, our cost of sales also include energy costs, which amounted to €65.6 million or 11.6% of our cost of sales for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022 (2021: €41.3 million or 9.0%; 2020: €35.1 million or 9.0% of our cost of sales). Operating our state-of-the-art technologies requires a significant amount of energy. Rising energy prices, energy price fluctuations as well as environmental levies or government incentives have had, and may continue to have, an impact on our margins. We therefore hedge against some of these price 70 ----- volatilities, in particular for our sites in Germany and Switzerland. For the financial years ended December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022, approximately 83%, 80% and 69%, respectively, of our electricity costs have been hedged and for the financial year ended December 31, 2023, we have hedged approximately 70% of our electricity costs (measured as a percentage of total GWh).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our capital expenditures (capex) focus on (a) targeted capacity expansions for new and existing products and debottlenecking projects in line with the specific customer demands (“Growth Capex”), (b) maintenance projects to continuously upgrade and optimize our facilities and increase asset reliability levels as well as adopting our facilities to the required regulatory and safety standards (“Maintenance Capex”), and (c) targeted plant upgrades programs (including our “Fit for Future” (F4F) capex program to upgrade Pratteln assets, which is expected to finish this year). Our cash capital expenditure for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 was €71.6 million (2021: €68.6 million; 2020: €60.0 million). For the financial year ended December 31, 2023 we expect capital expenditures to be in the mid-€60 million range. Our capex allocation follows a stringent prioritization process managed by our Executive Committee and board to review all projects regarding financial return, e.g., payback periods and return rates (predominantly Growth Capex), binding customer commitments as well as implications on asset availability and safety prior to approval. For Maintenance Capex, we focus on our capex allocation primarily on production lines with high margin potential and/or strong customer demand and efficiency projects, e.g., improvements of energy efficiency, to ensure adequate return rates from investments. For Growth Capex projects, we typically target EBITDA pay-back periods of approximately three years and return rates of approximately 25% internal rate of return secured by binding customer commitments, with customers signing either firm commitments for minimum volumes and/or contributing a share of the capex via a fixed facility fee. While this is not achieved in all our projects, we aim to strengthen our product portfolio over time with projects that either match our key criteria above or otherwise offer strategic opportunities. _Growth Capex_ Growth Capex accounted for slightly more than a third of our yearly capex spend and increased as a proportion of total capex from 2020 to 2021 as a result of additional capacity expansion projects for new products in Finland and Switzerland and has remained relatively constant as a proportion of total capex across 2021 and 2022. Growth investments are mostly focused on high-margin Crop Science products and Life Science. We partner with most of our CDMO customers through long-term contracts to deliver specialized active ingredients and precursors according to individualized requests, often requiring custom production lines and processes. As a result, a large share of our capex is invested in our CDMO business or in contracted capacity expansion for our Specialties products. A CDMO project development lifecycle of a new product can extend to up to 18 months in the customer request phase as well as a further 24 months of investment period before commercialization. As a result, we aim to have our customers take a share in the initial capex spend by entering into agreements with our clients to de-risk the investments, with our long-term contracts for a large part of our portfolio, most of which featuring either guaranteed volumes commitments for an initial period, up-front contributions to the capex requirements to set-up production or ‘take-or-pay’ clauses. In general, we aim to recover our capex investment within approximately three years from the start of commercialization and a typical production horizon for large, strategic products extends historically to over 10 years. Increasing our ability to onboard client projects, in 2019 we expanded our operations into the United States with the acquisition of Monitchem Kansas S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries, including the Jayhawk facility in Galena, Kansas, United States. Furthermore, as part of our capacity expansions at our multipurpose plants, we further expanded our production capacities in Kokkola (Finland) to serve our customers in connection with already secured and newly developed products for the Crop Science market. _Maintenance Capex_ Overall, Maintenance Capex remained relatively constant as a proportion of total capex across 2020 and 2021, increasing in 2022, in line with our growing asset base. We allocate ongoing Maintenance Capex to support differentiation and competitiveness of our existing plants. Our Maintenance Capex requirement is mainly driven by the corrosive nature of substances used in our production 71 ----- process, making periodical inspection and maintenance of our plants and production chains necessary. Furthermore, our Maintenance Capex helps to ensure asset availability, productivity, energy efficiency and optimized performance. A significant proportion of yearly Maintenance Capex is allocated to maintenance works for our production plants with Pratteln (as our largest site), accounting for a large share of yearly Maintenance Capex expenses. _F4F capex_ In 2018, we began the “Fit for Future” (“F4F”) capex program for our site in Pratteln. The project, which is expected to finish this year, covers key aspects of our operations and comprises multiple initiatives to further improve and safeguard asset safety, reliability, availability and compliance. Our F4F investment projects offer returns via opportunities for price increases as well as additional volumes from the respective production lines.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations for the first and fourth quarters of the year are generally stronger than our results of operation for the second and third quarters, largely due to seasonal factors in demand from our Crop Science customers. We typically experience an increase in production levels in the first and fourth quarters of the year in order to meet the stronger demand in those quarters in line with increased demand for Crop Science products in the Northern Hemisphere each spring prior to the growing season. In addition, we and other chemical companies, including certain suppliers and customers, generally schedule repairs of machinery and facility turnarounds (scheduled shutdowns of production units or facilities for maintenance) in the summer months, which may result in lower sales in the second and third quarters relative to the first and fourth quarters of a given year. To the extent possible, we try to coordinate such repair schedules with our customers and suppliers. Seasonal fluctuations including adverse weather conditions may adversely affect certain of our markets and customers, thereby impacting our quarterly results disproportionately due to the seasonal nature of our business. For example, in the 2020 summer, the dry weather in Europe affected some of our customers and therefore impacted demand. See “Risk Factors⸺Risks Related to Our Business⸺Seasonal fluctuations may impact our _sales and cash flows.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Generally, in the financial year 2020, the Group’s business model proved to be resilient throughout the coronavirus pandemic, as we experienced resilient end-customer demand from the Crop Science and Life Science markets, benefitting from predictable revenues under existing long-term supply contracts for a large part of our portfolio. Furthermore, we were able to maintain well-managed supply chains and ensure reliable production and delivery channels to customers. While we have experienced some delays in raw material deliveries and were required to adapt our processes in procurement, inventory management and trade working capital strategies, the COVID-19 pandemic and the global supply chain and transportation network disruptions did not have a material impact on our results of operations in 2020, 2021 and 2022, underlying the resilience of the business model. COVID-19-related restrictions impacted Crop Science production in the first quarter of the financial year 2020 but normalized following the easing of lockdown restrictions. Whilst the COVID-19 restrictions did impact labor availability, both in terms of production and field work, many countries deemed the agricultural sector to be of considerable importance in order to maintain food security, therefore, restrictions on movement were less stringent than in other industries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Manufacturing Capacity Utilization and Planned maintenance turnarounds
Subsubsection Text: Utilization rates of our manufacturing capacity is a significant driver of our profitability, since our cost of sales comprises variable and fixed components. Fixed costs include plant related and overhead costs such as personnel expenses, energy costs, repair and maintenance expenses, which are largely independent from production volumes. We operate our facilities at generally high utilization rates and continuously focus on further improving these utilization rates. To maintain the efficiency of our assets, we regularly undergo scheduled maintenance shutdowns in order to carry out required maintenance activities, perform necessary inspections and tests or accommodate for shutdowns of key suppliers. We refer to these scheduled outages as “turnarounds”. The number and length of such turnarounds carried out in any given period impact our operating results and the level of our capital expenditures. 72 ----- However, we try to coordinate such repair schedules with our customers and suppliers as they may also need to undergo “turnarounds” at the same time. Furthermore, for our multi-purpose plants that produce customized and specialized chemicals, whenever we change production from one product to another, we factor in the ‘switchover’ times required to clean the reactor vessels. This requires us to shut down operations of a production unit within a production facility until the cleaning is completed. See “⸺Seasonality.” Our production facilities undergo regular maintenance which requires the outage of a production unit or the entire facility for a period of two to four weeks per year. Repair and maintenance costs in connection with such regular maintenance can be up to several millions. In the past three years, our repair and maintenance expenses amounted to €27.5 million in 2022 (2021: €21.4 million; 2020: €20.8 million).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are also influenced by the evolving nature of regulations impacting the industries in which our customers operate. In particular for our Exclusives and Specialties product group, certain customers produce pharmaceuticals subject to evolving requirements, or complex Crop Science products subject to developing rules around permitted usage. Such requirements have become increasingly extensive and complex, requiring specialist CDMO partners with strong technical expertise and assets fitting into global supply chains of Crop Science players. As a result of these changing requirements, we have taken a strategic decision in the past to phase out certain services and products with lower margin to focus on our core strengths and expertise in Crop Science, which offers us a more attractive business case and return on investment. Such strategic portfolio management decisions have temporarily negatively affected our revenue for the respective years but have freed up capacities and avoided cost increases for the expansion in our core business. See also “Regulation, _Environmental, Health and Safety Measures” and “Risk Factors⸺Risks related to the Industry in which we Operate⸺We are subject to stringent environmental, health and safety laws and regulations across multiple jurisdictions. We are highly regulated and may incur significant costs to maintain compliance with, or address liabilities under, environmental, health and safety laws and regulations applicable to our business.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue from contracts with customers is recognized in the amount of the consideration the Group expects to receive in exchange for the goods or services when the customer obtains control of the goods or services. Control is considered to be transferred when the customer can direct the use of the goods or services and can obtain all substantial remaining benefits from them. We primarily generate income from the sale of goods. For the Exclusives and Specialties product group, revenue from specific customer contracts is recognized over time. In these cases our performance obligation consists in the creation of an asset without an alternative use to us and we have an enforceable right to payment for the performance obligation completed to date. These contractually enforceable rights are recognized and disclosed within ‘Accounts receivable, trade’ if already shipped, or otherwise within ‘Contract assets’. Certain customer contracts for the Exclusives product group foresee non-refundable up-front capital expenditure fees, which are paid by the customer at the beginning of the investment project. These advance payments are recognized in the consolidated statement of profit or loss in proportion to the performance used by the customer during the contract period (output method). The outstanding performance obligation is disclosed in the balance sheet at each reporting date. If a customer contract does not meet these criteria, the customer obtains control of the goods at a specific point in time, and the corresponding sales revenue is hence recognized at a specific point in time. Determination of the point in time at which the customer obtains control of the goods occurs in the context of an overall assessment of the circumstances which considers the existence of a present claim to payment, the legal title to the goods, actual physical possession of the goods, the transfer of risks and rewards as well as customer acceptance. The transfer of risks and rewards takes into account the underlying terms of delivery (especially the International Commercial Terms, or “Incoterms”) and is of particular practical significance. According to these principles, sales revenue from the sale of goods is generally recognized upon delivery. 73 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales comprises the costs of materials and supplies, personnel expenses, proportionate depreciation and amortization, repairs and maintenance, energy, analysis and ecology, production overheads, plant overheads as well as costs of packaging the products.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: General and administrative expenses comprise personnel expenses, legal and consultancy costs and other external services as well as insurance premiums.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Distribution and logistics expenses comprise the costs of personnel expenses, proportionate depreciation on property, plant and equipment and intangible assets as well as transport costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Research costs are recognized immediately as expense when they are incurred. They comprise wages and salaries, cost of materials, proportionate depreciation on property, plant and equipment and overheads. Development costs are only capitalized if, on the basis of various criteria, it is probable that the capitalized amount will be covered by future income.

Subsubsection Text: Financial result contains interest income and expenses as well as foreign currency gains and losses. Interest income and expenses is recognized using the effective interest rate method.

Subsubsection Text: Revenue of the Exclusives and Specialties product group increased by €62.0 million or 16.9% from €367.3 million in the financial year ended December 31, 2021 to €429.3 million in the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The strong revenue growth in Exclusives was both driven by higher volumes and by positive pricing effects, as increased raw material prices were partially passed on to our customers. Revenue of Specialties increased, driven by positive pricing effects and a continued strong demand for high-value products in regulated markets, such as pharmaceutical, personal care, food and animal feed as well as in the automotive, aerospace and agrochemical industries. Revenue of the Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals product group increased by €104.5 million or 47.1% from €221.7 million in the financial year ended December 31, 2021 to €326.2 million in the financial year ended December 31, 2022, benefiting from favorable pricing effects. Revenue of our Advanced Intermediates increased mainly due to our MCA products. The increase in revenue of these products was due to positive price effects resulting from the partial pass-through of increased raw material prices and supply chain costs, which were partially passed through via formula selling prices with a time lag. Revenue of Base Products increased, supported by a strong demand and a significant increase in achieved price levels of acetic acid and caustic soda, which has reached an all-time high. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales increased by €104.7 million, or 22.7%, from €461.0 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021 to €565.7 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. As a percentage of revenues, cost of sales amounted to 74.9% of our revenues in the financial year ended December 31, 2022 and 78.3% of our revenues in the financial year ended December 31, 2021. Subsubsection Text: 79 ----- Revenue of the Exclusives and Specialties product group increased by €55.1 million or 17.6% from €312.2 million in the financial year ended December 31, 2020 to €367.3 million in the financial year ended December 31, 2021, driven by a strong demand from our agrochemical customers for Exclusives. The strong revenue growth was both driven by higher volumes and by positive pricing effects, as increased raw material prices were partially passed on to our customers. Revenue of Specialties increased, driven by positive pricing effects and a continued strong demand for high-value products in regulated markets, such as pharmaceutical, personal care, food and animal feed as well as automotive, aerospace and agrochemical industries. In 2020, a fire incident at our Pratteln site led to a partial standstill of the chlorine value chain, which negatively impacted our revenues in both product groups. In addition, the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a temporary decline in the price for caustic soda, resulting in temporarily lower 2020 revenues. Adjusted for the impact of the Pratteln site fire incident, all our product groups still experienced strong growth: in our Exclusives and Specialties product group the strong growth of 17.6% resulted from project wins and strong demand for our existing portfolio of products, growth in innovative niche specialties products and overall very resilient demand in Crop and Life sciences, while Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals exhibited a 23.1% year-on-year growth in revenue which was principally due to the start of the caustic soda price recovery, continued successful partial pass-through of a certain portion of raw material price increases to customers and a largely stable volume development and, for some Specialties and Advanced Intermediates, the need for Western suppliers to de-risk supply chains. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales increased by €70.8 million, or 18.1%, from €390.2 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2020 to €461.0 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021. As a percentage of revenues, cost of sales amounted to 79.3% of our revenues in the financial year ended December 31, 2020 and 78.3% of our revenues in the financial year ended December 31, 2021. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Reported EBITDA means net result for the period adding back taxes on income, financial results, amortization and depreciation. (2) Adjusted EBITDA means result for the period adding back taxes on income, financial result, amortization and depreciation and adjustments for expenses and income not related to the operational performance of the business activities, such as strategic projects, restructuring and reorganization measures, financial impacts of natural disasters, property damage insurance compensations, as well as valuation impacts resulting from curtailments or modifications to pension or post-retirement benefits schemes and purchase price allocations. Neither EBITDA nor Adjusted EBITDA is a performance indicator recognized under IFRS. The EBITDA and the Adjusted EBITDA reported is not necessarily comparable to the performance figures published by other companies as EBITDA or Adjusted EBITDA or the like. Adjusted EBITDA increased by €34.8 million, or 27.2%, from €127.8 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021 to €162.6 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Historical growth in Adjusted EBITDA was driven by favorable market conditions and a continued strong demand across both product groups in 2022, in particular due to an increase in pricing resulting in a higher margin for our products from customers in our Exclusives and Specialties business as well as positive pricing effects in our Advanced Intermediates and Base Chemicals business. Adjusted EBITDA increased by €14.9 million, or 13.2%, from €112.9 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2020 to €127.8 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021. The growth in Adjusted EBITDA was driven by resilient top-line growth and new product introductions, paired with shift to higher margin Exclusives and Specialties business, our ability to partially pass on raw material prices efficiently and substantial benefits from operating leverage as we focus on efficient plant and overhead management. The strong growth in Adjusted EBITDA was achieved despite supply chain disruptions in early 2021. In the first half of the financial year 2021, the Group’s performance was negatively affected by extreme winter weather conditions in the Gulf coast area in the U.S., impacting the business operations of our raw material suppliers. These suppliers were forced to declare the occurrence of a force majeure event for various products such as, for example, Acetic Acid. This resulted in a loss of already contracted business (purchase orders), which was not compensated by insurance and was normalized as part of non-recurring items. 83 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our principal sources of funds have been cash generated from our operating activities, borrowings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and sale of receivables under the Securitization Program and the Factoring Program. Our principal uses of cash are for capital expenditures, to fund debt service obligations and for working capital. As of December 31, 2022, we had cash and cash equivalents of €69.9 million. Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is expected to be our operating cash flows. We will also have access to the New Revolving Credit Facility to service our working capital and general corporate needs. The continued availability of the New Revolving Credit Facility is dependent upon certain conditions as described further under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement.” In addition, our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which, in turn, depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. See “Risk Factors.” Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities, together with available borrowings under the New Revolving Credit Facility, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Financial Year ended December 31, 2021 compared with the Financial Year ended December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: _Cash Flow from Operating Activities_ Cash flow from operating activities increased by €54.3 million from €96.4 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021 to €150.7 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to the significant increase in Reported EBITDA. Furthermore, despite rising raw material and energy prices, net working capital increased at a slower rate than in the previous period. _Cash Flow from Investing Activities_ Cash flow used in investing activities increased by €4.2 million from €67.3 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021 to €71.5 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to investments into measures regarding asset reliability and availability with respect to our production sites as well as contracted growth projects, including our “Fit for Future” program. _Cash Flow from Financing Activities_ Cash flow used in financing activities increased by €8.6 million from €42.4 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021 to €51.0 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to an increase in drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in the amount of €5.0 million and an increase in interest rates as a result of such larger amount drawn thereunder. In addition, other financial debt decreased to a cash outflow of €2.4 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2022 resulting from a sale of non-current assets and includes proceeds that were not passed on to other members of a consortium until the financial year 2022. 84 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Financial Year ended December 31, 2020 compared with the Financial Year ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: _Cash Flow from Operating Activities_ Cash flow from operating activities decreased by €28.1 million from €124.5 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2020 to €96.4 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021. While our Reported EBITDA increased significantly from €110.7 million to €117.5 million as a result of strong business growth, our working capital requirements also increased, in particular higher inventories and accounts receivables which reduced our cash flow from operating activities year-on-year. _Cash Flow from Investing Activities_ Cash flow used in investing activities increased by €7.5 million from €59.8 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2020 to €67.3 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was principally due to higher investments in property, plant and equipment in 2021, in particular at the sites in Pratteln and in Kokkola. Material investments in 2021 included maintenance, safety and reliability measures as well as the expansion of production capacities for the Exclusives and Specialties product group, which were higher than in 2020. _Cash Flow from Financing Activities_ Cash flow used in financing activities increased by €2.2 million from €40.1 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2020 to €42.3 million for the financial year ended December 31, 2021. While interest and financing fees paid decreased from €44.3 million to €44.0 million year-on-year. In addition, we utilized our Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in 2020 by €10.0 million compared to an additional utilization of only €5.0 million in 2021. This was due to higher net working capital financing needs, which increased as a result of a strong business performance and rising raw material and energy prices. The change in other financial debt (€2.5 million) was a result of the sale of fixed assets and reflects proceeds in 2021 which were forwarded to other members of a consortium in 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our capital expenditures primarily relate to maintenance projects, facility upgrades and capacity expansion projects, optimization and de-bottlenecking. A significant portion of our yearly capex expenditure is allocated to maintenance costs, a big proportion of which is required for our plant in Pratteln. Growth Capex accounted for slightly more than a third of our yearly capex spend and increased as a proportion of total capex from 2020 to 2021 and has remained relatively constant as a proportion of total capex across 2021 and 2022. See “⸺Factors _Affecting our Results of Operations⸺Capital Expenditures and Capacity Expansion.” A relatively small part of_ our capital expenditures is spent on intangible assets, including information and communications technology, research and development.

MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Group Net Working Capital remained relatively stable at €60.8 million as of December 31, 2021 and €59.4 million as of December 31, 2022. Group Net Working Capital increased from €44.0 million as of December 31, 2020 to €60.8 million as of December 31, 2021 principally due to an increase in inventories and accounts receivable, trade while an increase in accounts payable, trade partially offset this development. Higher inventories in 2021 reflect increased raw material prices and the build-up of buffer stock to safeguard against potential supply chain disruptions. Furthermore, as of December 31, 2021, accounts receivable, trade increased by €25.9 million to €70.5 million and within this figure, trade receivables sold under a customer’s reverse factoring program amounted to €11.4 million as of December 31, 2021 as compared to €9.9 million as of December 31, 2020. We anticipate that our trade working capital requirements will vary due to changes in raw material costs and product off-takes by customers, which affect inventory and accounts receivable levels. Trade working capital levels typically develop in line with raw material prices, although timing factors can affect flows of capital. We expect to fund our working capital requirements with cash generated from operations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our provisions for pensions and similar obligations amounted to €18.1 million as of December 31, 2022. Our reported pension provisions related to obligations to employees under pension plans. We operated various pension schemes in accordance with the local laws and practices in the countries in which we operate. In Germany, retirement benefits are provided under the pension fund of the employees of the Hoechst Group VVaG. Retirement benefits for our employees in Switzerland are provided under the pension fund of CABB AG. The Swiss pension plan is a defined contribution scheme under Swiss GAAP. Retirement benefits for our employees in Finland are provided under the pension insurance company Ilmarinen Mutual Pension Insurance Company. Our provisions for pensions are described in greater detail in Note 26 to our 2022 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. As of December 31, 2022, we also had provisions for personnel obligations that amounted to €11.8 million. The personnel obligations include short-term benefits for holiday allowances and overtime, premiums and bonus payments, service anniversary payments, post-employment benefits and contributions to the Employers’ Liability Insurance Association (Berufsgenossenschaft).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2022, we had provisions for environmental and rehabilitation obligations that amounted to €1.1 million. The provision relates to expected costs of rehabilitating toxic waste sites in Switzerland as well as waste disposal at the production location in Kokkola, Finland. The future development of environmental costs depends on many factors including the rehabilitation method to be used, the extent of the rehabilitation measures as well as the shares attributable to the Group and to external parties. The amount of the provision is management’s best estimate of the future outflow of funds in connection with our environmental and rehabilitation obligations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill in the amount of €199.2 million is recognized in the consolidated statement of financial position for the financial year ended December 31, 2022. Goodwill is subject to an annual impairment test at on the basis of cashgenerating units a minimum by comparing its carrying amount with its recoverable amount. 87 ----- The goodwill impairment test is performed on the basis of cash-generating units (CGUs) by comparing the recoverable amount with the carrying amount. Consistent with the internal management and reporting structure, the following three cash generating units have been identified: (i) CDMO – Europe, (ii) CDMO – North America, (iii) Non - CDMO. The CGUs reflect the lowest level within the entity at which goodwill is monitored for internal management purposes. The existing goodwill was allocated to the CGUs in accordance with the purchase price allocation in 2014 for the CGU CDMO – Europe and the CGU Non – CDMO resp. 2019 for the CGU CDMO – North America. The recoverable amount of the cash-generating units is calculated based on the fair value less costs to sell approach. The underlying cash flow projections are based on past experiences, current results and on the best estimate of the future development of influencing factors. Market assumptions, such as the development of the overall economy and the market growth are considered using external macroeconomical and industry-specific information sources. The required discounting of cash flows for impairment testing is calculated using the weighted average cost of capital rate after tax, which is determined using the capital asset pricing model. It comprises a risk-free interest rate, a market risk premium, and a spread for credit risk based on the respective industry-specific peer group. The fair value measurement was categorized as a level 3 fair value. The financial projections were approved by management and consist of a detailed planning period of five years. The annual impairment test was performed as of October 31, 2022. The recoverable amount of all CGU’s exceed their carrying amounts as of December 31, 2022 and as of December 31, 2021. No goodwill impairment was indicated. See Note 18 to our 2022 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Property, plant and equipment and intangible assets
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2022, we had intangible assets (excluding goodwill) with a balance sheet value of €95.2 million and property, plant and equipment with a balance sheet value of €578.9 million. Intangible assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable. Property, plant and equipment are tested annually for indications of impairment. If any such indication exists, estimates of the expected future cash flows from the utilization and potential disposal of these assets are made in order to assessing the impairment. The actual cash flows may differ significantly from the discounted future cash flows which are based on these estimates. Factors such as a change in the planned utilization of buildings, machinery and equipment, technical ageing or utilization levels of installations which are lower than original forecasts may reduce the useful service life or may result in an impairment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2022, we reported provisions of €18.1 million for pensions and similar obligations. The valuation of these pension provisions is influenced by assumptions regarding the future development of wages and salaries or pensions as well as interest rates. In Germany, retirement benefits are provided via the pension fund of the employees of the Hoechst Group VVaG. The Swiss employees of the Group are insured with the pension fund of CABB AG, Pratteln, Switzerland. The retirement benefits of the Finnish employees are processed via the pension insurance company Ilmarinen Ltd. The calculations of the assets and liabilities recognized with regard to these facilities are based on statistical and actuarial calculations. In particular, the present value of the defined benefit obligation depends on assumptions such as the discount rate and the pension growth rate used for calculating the present value of the future pension obligations. Future salary increases and increases in the other benefits to employees also influence the calculation of the present value of future pension obligations. In addition, the independent actuaries engaged by us also use statistical data such as probability of departure and life expectancy of the insured parties for their assumptions. The discount rate for the actuarial calculations of the German and Finnish defined benefit obligations was determined by applying the Mercer Pension Yield Curve Approach (MYC). The data and methodology used to create the MYC is reviewed periodically by Mercer to ensure consistency and improved estimates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Provisions for environment and rehabilitation relate to the responsibility of the Group in relation to the cost of asbestos remediation and the rehabilitating of certain legacy issues. The rehabilitation costs are borne by the major waste contributors of the past, whereby the share of CABB AG is defined in accordance with a fixed distribution key. The amount of the provision is the best estimate of management for the future outflow of funds in connection with the rehabilitation obligations. Although the estimations and assumptions are regularly reviewed and updated, the actual outcome can significantly differ from the current best estimate. The rehabilitation of the largest landfill 88 ----- site is completed, which leads to the next phase of renaturation of the site. Thus, it is possible that additional costs may occur which exceed the recognized provisions. As of December 31, 2022, we had recognized environmental provisions in the amount of €1.1 million.

Subsubsection Text: Accruals for deferred taxes are recognized for tax losses carried forward. The recognition of deferred tax assets on tax losses carried forward requires management estimates to the extent that it is probable that taxable profits will be available against which the losses can by utilized. If there is doubt regarding the extent to which the tax loss carry-forwards can be realized, appropriate impairments are recognized in relation to the deferred tax assets as required.

Subsubsection Text: Our preparation of the audited consolidated financial statements requires management to make assumptions, undertake estimates and exercise judgment that affect the reported amount of assets and liabilities at the balance sheet date and the reported amounts of sales and expenses during the financial period. See Note 3 to our 2022 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. All assumptions, expectations and forecasts used as a basis for certain estimates within the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements represent good-faith assessments of our future performance for which management believes there is a reasonable basis. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: With effect from January 1, 2022, we applied certain new and amended standards and interpretations published by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and endorsed by the European Union. The amendments had no material impact on the Group’s financial position or results of operations: - Amendments to IFRS 3 Business Combinations, IAS 16 Property, Plant and Equipment, IAS 37 Provisions, Contingent Liabilities and Contingent Assets as well as Annual Improvements to IFRS 2018 – 2020. The amendments to IFRS include an update of the reference of the Conceptual Framework in IFRS standards. Furthermore, an additional provision was added to IFRS 3 stating that an acquirer must apply the provisions from IAS 37 and IFRIC 21 rather than the Conceptual Framework when identifying assumed liabilities within the scope of these standards. - The amendments to IAS 16 specify that income received by a company through the sale of items produced while the asset is being brought to its location and into working order must be recognized with the associated costs in profit or loss. Including these items in the cost of the asset is not permissible. - The amendments to IAS 37 specify which costs an entity includes in determining the cost of fulfilling a contract for the purpose of assessing whether the contract is onerous. The amendments apply for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2022 to contracts existing at the date when the amendments are first applied. At the date of initial application, the cumulative effect of applying the amendments is recognized as an opening balance adjustment to retained earnings or other components of equity, as appropriate. The comparatives are not restated. - The annual improvements to IFRS 2018 – 2020 pertain to amendments to IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments, whereby only such costs and fees which are paid to the lender by the company and vice versa are to be included in the “10% test” for the purpose of derecognition of financial liabilities. Costs or fees paid to other third parties may not to be included. Moreover, they pertain to minor amendments to IFRS 1 First-Time Adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards, IAS 41 Agriculture, and to the explanatory examples of IFRS 16 Leases. 89 -----
